It was cold and drizzling when we went, but the gardens and lovely walkways lifted our spirits!Food vendors on site, plus a restuarant ( which we didnt try). Lovely clean amenities too!
Peaceful place to relax. What a lovely place to sit and relax! I enjoyed the sound of the water stream, people looking at the many butterflies and take a rest from noisy and busy Hongkong.

The park is truly amazing. Beautiful park in the middle of the shopping madness.Yes it is mostly man made but that doesn't matter when it provides cool shade under its trees and an excellent covered aviary filed with exotic birds. Beautiful greenery of various types, tropical flowers and plants and all labelled in English. Water lakes with Coy and turtles, waterfalls and a botanical museum and Aviary. It can be easily accessed from the beside the Peak Tram station and has easy access to the centrally located Admiralty Metro station.Highly recommend

Haven in the hustle anf bustle. Beautifully laid out park with lakes, waterfalls, lovely statues and a fabulous (free-entry) aviary with amazing exotic birds flying overhead. There's also a good restaurant with views of the waterfall.

Beautiful oasis. This lovely park is a beautiful respite from the hustle bustle of Hong Kong streets. At every turn there is something of beauty. The aviary is a fun place to observe many different species of birds. The park is very well tended to.

A pleasant stroll when you need a breather from Central. Small but enjoyable park to stroll around. The aviary is worth visiting (open until 5pm, free entry) to see the exotic bird species flying around. There is also a zoological and botanical gardens nearby.Children's play area, toilets and refreshment facilities are all available. Pleasant fountain area to sit down and relax on a fine weather day.

Outstanding Park in Hong Kong Central District. Right smack in the Central District of Hong Kong Island (Victoria) is a beautiful park that provides the opportunity to relax among the multistorey skyscrapers surrounding the park. It is free for everyone, with a small pond and waterfall that provides an added tranquility to a very busy and cosmopolitan surroundings. There is also an aviary with a number of very beautiful species of birds from Southeast Asia. Is easily accessible by the MTR (mass transit railway or Metro) Central Station or by bus. Well worth an hour to visit and enjoy a respite from the busy sight seeing schedule.
a small park for the community. Went there bc I was staying v close and it appeared in the map from hotel... It can be nice to walk outside if weather allows but there is no pretty view.

Lovely and free to the public. The aviary is absolutely spectacular. The park reminded my son and I a bit of Washington DC or New York - a bit of green in a bustling city. Admission is free and signs point to the park beginning around Central. Easily accessible via Metro or bus (Central station, Star Ferry, etc).

Thank goodness they haven't built over it!. As part of our wonderings around Hong Kong Island we walked through this delightful park. It has lots of water features, exotic plants, an aviary, a cactus house and all of it was beautifully done. Plenty to do for all ages

A real surprise. Our hotel is opposite the entrance and we had to walk through to go to the Peak Terminus (visiting a garden wasn't on our list of must see attractions) and we were delighted. So, on the return journey took some time to wander around the park. It's well tended, very clean and peaceful. Good for young and old alike. The waters here are full of fish and turtles. There's an aviary which we saw from a distance and heard but didn't go up to. There are plenty of steps to see the park on different aspects so some areas will be difficult to reach if you have mobility problems. What surprised me most was that all the plants and trees were labelled. How often have you stood and deliberated what a plant is with no way of looking it up?

Beautiful Park. This park was at hardly at 5 minute walk from our Hotel Marriott, so been here for morning walk. What a beautiful park it is, with various fountains and some small natural fall. We saw Christian couple coming over there for their wedding photoshoot with flower girls/boys . It was so nice to see them in their beautiful wedding gowns. Otherwise also, this park is truly amazing. Must a visit.!!

Nice place to visit after peak. If you go to the peak and have time after, worth to visit Hong Kong park. It's not really big but has many interesting buildings/attractions and a lot of different types of trees and birds. It has nice collection of tea ware, but now it's partly under construction.

Stunning. We stumbled upon this by accident and were so happy we did.
There is a free aviary with 600 birds, all beautifully coloured, healthy looking and flying around.
The rest of the park is pretty, immaculately clean and very nice to spend an hour or two in.

Good place to get away from the hustle and bustle. The highlight is supposed to be the Edward Youde Aviary, which frankly underwhelmed me - but it was very cold and may be the birds were all tucked up somewhere warm?? The rest probably not of much interest for UK visitors, except for the space and peace.

Beautiful garden of tranquil beauty in a crazy city!. We were staying at the Conrad opposite this garden, great for a peaceful walk day or night. Many water features, birds, fish and statues by Anthony Gormley in the park and on top of surrounding buildings, a little strange to see these statues on the edge, they look like real people about to jump!. Overall the park is beautiful refuge from the noise of the streets, plenty of seating and places to buy refreshments. A great photo shoot!, worth a visit.

for bird lovers!. The aviary was incredible. It has a walkway so you can go in and see the birds up close (not too close--nobody wants avian flu). The rest of the park was very picturesque with lovely walking paths.
Beautiful retreat in a busy city. It was lovely to stroll through the park. It is well laid out with fountains, lakes and avairy. Lovely break from the city.

Worth a vistit. The park offers a very pleasant walk through the aviary and around the lakes and waterfall. It's a green and quieter place in the heart of Central surrounded by skyscrapers, just the opposite the Peak Tram station. I don't approve the birds in cages so don't recommend the "bird exhibition". Overall surely worth visiting.

Peace in the heart of HK. Surprisingly this place was peaceful considering its location the heart of HK.Really nice place to have a wander and take a break from the hustle and bustle of the city. Tea Museum was closed on the day we visited so can't comment but did enjoy the wee restaurant inside the park.Handy to The Peak and easy to get to.
Was great to find some green among the skyscrapers. After navigating through all the above street level passages or underpasses and stuff, we were glad to find this place - peaceful and green.

Like a Central Park in New York City. OF course, NY Central Park is larger, older and... flat.Here is a small (by NY criteria), but very beautiful and well kept park in the middle of Hong Kong business quarter. Don't forget to visit Tea museum.
Relax in the evening. Situated in Central, this park is green amidst the concrete jungle around it. Nice place to spend the evening.

An oasis in the heart of the city. Right in the middle of one of the densest city on the planet, there is this beautiful, well used park. It is home to the tea museum, the bottom terminus of the Peak Tram, a great aviary, restaurants, historical buildings and spectacular views.

Little paradise in the middle of Hong Kong. The park is so beautiful and helps you to relax after a long walk through the busy city. You still have amazing views of the cities sky line but you are still away from all the noise. There are some nice hidden paths that are worth exploring.
Great park in central. Hong Kong park is a well laid out park in central with some special attractions like the bird house. Kids can find nice play grounds here.
Touch of nature. I love jogging around this park. It's always green and well maintained. There is even a small pond with fish and turtles that you may be lucky enough to see.

In the midst of skyscrapers. What a great place to relax and escape the big city hustle. Being in the center of HK island, the park is pretty big of what I expected.
Nice place for a half an hour break in peace while exploring HK.

Amazing, even the rain. We found this park by mistake when heading to tram terminus. Wow, what an amazing place , so much to see and do. Definitely make this. Place to visit even on a drizzly day, we still had a great time.
City escape. Lovely gardens with plenty going on around you, tai chi, dancing, fitness training, flamingos, aviaries, maze and history.

Beautiful park in the middle of a city. Well worth a visit. Free admission to a beautiful park in central Hong Kong, includes the Edward Youde aviary and some stunning landscaping. Pool in the centre attracts lots of wildlife and is home to many turtles.

Surprise in the middle of the City - not to be missed. Visited the Park on the way back from Victoria Peak. Its right across the road from Victoria Peak ticket counters. Its an oasis in the middle of the city. Very well maintained with walking paths, trees, place for children to play. The most amazing part is the Aviary - which you walk through. Once you enter it, it feels you are in a jungle. We encountered lots of birds, several of them perched on the banisters, just an arm's length away. Had fun taking lots of photos with the birds at such close quarters.

Good park. A nice spot. Steep and hemmed in by skyscrapers which gives a different feel.
The. Conservatory was a bit average, but I really liked the walk through aviary.
Nice lakes and fountains.
Nice park on the way to Victoria Peak Tram. Get off at Admiralty station and walk the park on the way to the tram. A nice park in the middle of the city.

Perfect place for a peaceful interlude.. This is a large park with an aviary. Very peaceful with water in ponds, water falls etc. The aviary is well worth climbing what I felt were 200 steps ( I am in my late 60's!) and there is a lot of information about the birds. I was there on a Sunday and the Marriage Registry was busy as I saw three weddings around the park. Relaxing but interesting too.

Short guide to Hong Kong Park, Aviary, Lakes, Conservatory, Museums, Resto, Stadium, Wedding Registry, Flagstaff House. Going early in the morning to HK park. The place is free of admission and very near to the terminal for the Victoria peak tram. A quite garden with tall trees. HK park features a sizable Aviary, caged birds display, tai chi court, observatory tower, conservatory, a colosseum, artificial lakes, waterfall, river, wedding registry house, museum of teaware, a gallery, two fountains and a restaurant. Early in the morning, the Aviary has already been visited by bird watchers and bird photographers, the birds are not too plenty, probably 12 species, some can be sighted within 1-2 meters. The tai chi court displays a not so impressive Chinese architecture and garden, older people are doing tai chi there. Inside the tai chi court is a 105 steps observatory tower viewing 360 degree of the park, including view to the white-blue Saint John’s cathedral and the iconic Bank of China office tower. The conservatory has two parts, dry plants and humid plants. Cacti displays with government warning not to touch the plant. The humid plant is more interesting with gushing water and humid air displaying ferns and green plants. The lakes has some waterfall and they have turtle on “islands”, with nice view to the skycrapers behind the trees. The wedding registry is a small building, conserved for its historical significance. The museum of teaware and KS Lo gallery is nearby. A museum of teawares inside HK park near the exit. An old architecture building, known as the Flagstaff House, some part undergone renovation and inaccessible. The display is disappointingly as some looks like replicas rather than the real ones. It highlights many design of teapots during many era of Chinese culture. But mostly are from more recent era, after 1800s. Two water fountains at the exit. HK park is much nicer than Kowloon park.The museum of teaware/ Flagstaff House is the oldest remaining western architecture in HK. The museum is sponsored by the founder of Vitasoy, a maker of popular soy drinks.
Just another small park. A small park between the skyscrapers. Nice place to stop by for a short while, but nothing really special.

A lovely place to visit.. I loved walking around this park. Some people don't seem to like the fact the buildings are so close and they think it ruins the look of the park, however, I think it enhances it. I love just walking around, seeing the trees, then looking up and seeing the buildings right behind looking down at you. As the buildings themselves are very nice it works well.There is a fountain here that a lot of people enjoy running into, just be careful on the steps into the fountain as they can get a bit slippery.There are ponds there with fish and turtles and I think one has frogs in it that I could hear but could never see, maybe you can find them?It costs nothing, you can walk in and enjoy the scenery. If you enjoy taking lots of photos when on holiday you will find lots of good photos to take here.There are toilets and food to buy too. Definitely worth a visit.
Chinese Products Expo. Very fun walk around , seeing and buying things, very addictive nteresting and enjoyable , big crowd
Calming park. It's quite calm and beautiful small park. Maybe not worth to come here for only that reason, but if one is close by one should take a break here.
Strange but Wonderful. Such a funny place in the middle of the city, but a nice walk for those wondering around the city anyway!
LOVELY GREEN LUNG IN THE CONCRETE JUNGLE. Lovely escape from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Remove yourself from the noise and chaos of the city.
great park. its one of the best parks in hong kong, very quiet, doesn't have a lot of people , it's very clean and safe. i was there around afternoon and i like it very much

A nice break from the busy city. This quite large park in Hong Kong is a nice break from the busy life of Hong Kong. It's nicely arranged, in different areas. They have a space with beautiful tropical birds, other areas with special plants and ponds and cascades. It's a relaxing place worth visiting.
Green Area. Glad to see that there are still green parks within the city though massive construction of high rise and infrastructures are in progress.

small park but things to see. I visit this park almost every week. Just last weekend I visited the aviary, where you walk into the "cage" yourself to see the birds without fence between you. This park is small and even small kids and elderly can enjoy it. A big plus is that it is centrally located with free admission. There are several entrances/exits, you may come from the entrance near Pacific Place from the east, or near Peak Tram Terminal from the west. This park is managed by the City Council/government, gardeners changed the pots of flowers and decorations according to seasons and festivals. Look forward to see the peach blossoms in Chinese New Year in early February this year.
Great!. What a great find in the middle of Hong Kong, lovely green park with waterfalls, fountains, and a bird Avery. There is no charge to enter, they even have free wifi in some parts

Hong Kong Park. The park was hard to find we had a have some help. Even following phone sat nav it seemed to send us wrong. When we finally found the opening we had been near it many times and not known. But the park was another gem of a place. Very easy walking on good paths. Lovely flowers and. Smallish bird park so once again don't forget your camera.

Nice a tranquil spot in the middle of huge megapolis.. This park is a great getaway for anyone willing to take a break from busy streets of HK. Fountain,waterfall, Ponds with Koi fish and water turtles, green alleys and Tea museum and nice Thai/Japanese restaurant cand be found here. Take an hour off your busy schedule and try to relax in this park. You won't regret it.

Greatly improves the walk from the hotel to the Peak Tram.. The high standard of cleanliness and planting in this park puts the UK to shame , there is no litter , Christmas decorations were not vandalised and the gardeners were much in evidence . The basking turtles and koi carp in the pools was relaxing to watch. There are various water features and it's a very enjoyable experience to briefly escape the city bustle.

A refreshing retreat. We stumbled into this park after deciding the lines for the Victoria Peak tram were too long. It's located a short walk away so we thought we'd check it out.It is a beautiful park with lots of different attractions. We went into the bird aviary which is free to enter and played a bit of bird bingo with the guide book. We also went into the conservatory, which is also free entry, and enjoyed the orchids and succulents. There is a nice Tai Chi Square with a tribute to SARS medical workers and a podium you can climb to get better views of the park. There are a few restaurants as well and we tried the Lock Cha tea shop which we enjoyed.All in all, we stumbled into this park by chance but would highly recommend it to anyone, especially budget travellers who are looking to enjoy some free attractions.

Beautiful hidden gem. Very nice to walk in, a green gem inside the skyscraper city. The park is smaller than we anticipated though. Bet very pritty. There are big walk-in cages with exotic plants and birds. It is a very nice trough the park to get to the Peak Tram.
Nice park. Very nice park in a busy part of town...a nice rest stop to recharge and have a nice break...reasonably peaceful

The main aviary is the highlight. Another piece of welcome open space in HK. Although it is a park with ornamental lakes (most contain small sun bathing turtles) and beautiful manicured gardens, it gets extremely busy on weekends when every man, woman and child ends up here (not to mention uni graduates and brides and grooms all having photographs taken from every angle). So the advice is to go during the week. The highlight is the main bird aviary - a huge net covered expanse with not-so-timid birds of all varying shapes and sizes endemic to HK. The lowlight is that there are other birds that are not displayed in the main aviary and it was quite sad to see majestic hornbills displayed in individual cages with no room to fly.
A place of peace in an urban jungle. We were not planning to see this but stumbled on it after a long walk, and escalator ride.It was so nice we spent the remainder of the day there.

Fantastic aquatic garden. This garden has beatiful water features, along with a sophicated, sprawling water garden with all kinds of exotic subtropical plants. It's well designed, executed and maintained. It's a gardener's delight.

Peace amongst the hustle and bustle. This is well worth a visit just to see that Hong Kong is not all shopping malls and skyscrapers. Incredibly peaceful and scenic. The aviary is excellent and popular with photographers. Ah, the serenity.

beautiful park. great park to stroll through with zoo animals, observatory and playgrounds for the little ones. On both sides of the peak tram, so nice place to run off some energy before standing in those lines.

300 times Excellent for affording a true respite from shopping malls and buildings. lucky for me I am a guest at The Island Shangri - La directly opposite The calm nature fish in the pond Need I say more ?

Urban oasis surprise. Stumbled on this park in the middle of Hong Kong while walking to the Peak Tram. We were delighted to find such a large urban forest in the middle of this densely packed city. The fountains, flowers and numerous birds we spotted were a delightful surprise.

In the heart of Central. Hong Kong Park is easily reached by MTR, just gets off at Admiralty Station, from Exit C follows the way to Pacific Place 2, then taking escalators uphill to our destination.It was opened on 23 May 1991, a joint project by the Urban Council (no longer existed after the re-organization) and the Royal Hong Kong Jockey Club.There is a clock tower at the entrance of the Fountain Plaza. Tortoises sun-bathe on the rocks and fishes swim leisurely inside the Artificial Lake. A walk-through aviary (9 a.m. to 5 p.m.) and caged display are well-maintained . There is an Arts Corner (only available on Saturday, Sunday and Public Holidays from 12:00 noon to 6:00 p.m.)at the outdoor area next to the Flagstaff House Museum of Tea Ware. Lock Cha Tea House locates at K.S. Lo Gallery where you can enjoy a cup of tea. Besides, you can also have a delicious meal at L16 restaurant. Olympic Square, Tai Chi Garden, Pebble Walking Trail, Conservatory Vantage Point, Cotton Tree Drive Marriage Registry and a Central and Western District time capsule all are inside the park. During weekends and public holidays, many domestic helpers from Philippines and Indonesia pack the park by taking photos here and there.

Easy free family friendly activity. We visited Hong Kong Park with my 1 yo son, 1 yo niece and 3 yo niece. We spent most of our time in the aviary. Everyone LOVED watching the birds! There is a big variety of birds and some birds are not shy and like to sing right beside visitors to the delight of all, especially the children. Highly recommend this activity to every family.

It's FREE in HK AND it's Great!. Walking around HK island on one of our day treks, we came across the HK park and enjoyed the very tropical surrounds and the opportunity to see many different monkey species. All for FREE in HK - now that IS amazing and every city should do the same.
Pretty. Hong Kong Park is a very nice place to relax but I preferred Kowloon Park which had more to see and better gardens.
Be sure to visit the aviary. In addition to walking through Hong Kong Park, be sure to go into the aviary and enjoy bird watching.

A Lovely Oasis. What a lovely surprise amidst the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Not the sort of park Australians are used to (no grass, no picnic areas) but a very nice place to stroll with and our 4Y0 son enjoyed the excellent playground facilities and the beautifully set out aviary. Great location atop of Pacific Plaza with the exit right at the Peak Tram.
Beauty. Beautiful escape from the city... In the middle of the city. I got overwhelmed my first day and this was like an oasis in the desert.
Amazing Space. A nice and quiet little hideaway in the middle of Hong Kong. If you wish to get away from the hustle and bustle of the big city then this is a good start.

Fantastic!. We found this by chance although it was only 2 minutes from our hotel - The Island Shangri-La. What a find! There is so much to do here and we spend several hours there during our 3 days in Hong Kong. Beautiful trees and flowers, lakes , birds, butterflies, a fantastic aviary and a very interesting Tea Museum. We never expected to find anything like this in Hong Kong.

Amazing city park. This park is situated on a hillside part of the city (Wan Chai) and is surrounded by skyscrapers like Bank of China Tower and other high and modern buildings.This provides an amazing contrast with this all manmade park, including pond and waterfall. It is certainly worthwhile to spend some time here. If you have some more time, also visit the aviary within the park, whereyou can spot beautiful exotic birds- and not miss them !

I love it here. I love it here so much I got married here at the registry office in the park. You can enjoy the park and the huge aviary or take a camera and watch the people getting married. I love the Chinese wedding dresses deep red with embossed embroidered golden Dragons and Phoenix lovely.

My secret place for coffee and newspaper. Whenever I am in Hong Kong this is my secret place I go mid-morning for my coffee and newspaperAn hour of my life I look forward toPeople don't really do 'outdoors' in Hong Kong - preferring instead for power lunches in various bespoke high end cafes, eateries and privates roof terracesThat said I tend to have the place much to myself and the abundant wildlife that has made the park and near by zoo it's permanent place of residenceHighly recommendedEnjoy :-)

Hilly and Full of Attractions. (Updating my review from 2013.)Hong Kong Park is beautiful, and a respite from the crowds. Make sure to walk through the spectacular aviary. Because the park is on a hill, the views of HK's most famous high-rises is spectacular. The Park houses the botanical gardens and the Flagstaff Tea Museum, where you can stop for some tea and snacks in a handsome restored mansion. On weekends, you can watch countless newly married couples pose for photographs in their wedding garb. The entrance to the park is on the downhill side, across the street from the Conrad Hotel. Don't try to get in from the uphill edge. Take the MTR to Admiralty Station and walk through the mall to the Park entrance.

A peaceful environment. In the middle of the busy, speedy and crowded Central City of Hong Kong, located this beautiful park. You wont believe it, you have to see and experience the sudden change in atmosphere as you enter this park. It open from 6am in the morning, and you can see people of all walks of life jogging, chatting, reading, feeding the fish or just admire the peaceful environment.
what can i say I married there. between all the sky scrapers a place of tranquility. cotton tree drive has a marriage chapel, quiet secluded place, starbucks around the corner for a small cupper

Below Expectations. Hong Kong Park is one of the top HK attractions on Tripadvisor, and we were told by locals that it is the best park in Hong Kong. Hence we may have set our expectations too high. It is a nice park for a morning stroll, but it just can't compare with other gardens we have visited, even back home in Singapore.The children's playground was disappointing. It was no different from what we can easily find in Singapore's housing estates. No special interesting features, hence my kids lost interest pretty quickly.The aviary was small, similar in size to the lory loft in Jurong Bird park. The birds were accustomed to being around humans, and weren't easily startled. Good photo opportunities there.The conservatory was located on top of a flight of steps. After seeing the lack-lustre aviary, we thought the conservatory may not be worth the effort and skipped it.The lake and the waterfall were just ok.By all means, take a stroll around if you happen to be in the vicinity. But I would not make a special effort to go.

Good view point. Like most parks in Hong Kong. Thie park is very clean. Beside that there is a great indoor place for birds where you can walk through. The view point has 105 steps. The view is ok, but not amazing. Eveyting inside the park is free of charge.

A quiet green grassy park in the centre of hectic traffic. This was a pleasant unexpected visit. There were people practicing tai chi and Fa,I lies out enjoying the sun and quiet. Interesting gardens and trees. Quite beautiful and peaceful.

Great!. Every city should have a park as pretty as this one. Each time you go around a corner you find another attraction and it's all free. There is a bird aviary, a children's playground, a tea house and many fountains.

Do not attempt this with a pushchair!. This park is an extension of the concrete jungle - the aviary is quite nice but other than that there is concrete paths, a pond, a playground, some fountains and lots and lots of steps that make taking toddlers and pushchairs there a nightmare.

An Oasis in the City. A wonderful park located in the heart of the city. Interesting fountains and pathways. We spent a lot of time in the avery and watching the butterflies. A great space for some nature time.

Beautiful treasure in the middle of the hustle and bustle. We strolled through this park a couple of times as it is very near the Conrad Hotel, where we stayed. It is a nice break from the busyness of the city!

A must see. The park is an oasis of tranquility and beauty in the middle of a hectic Hong Kong.
A beautiful lake,flowers and a tea museum which is interesting.

Greenery in the middle of hustle and bustle. This is a surprisingly quiet sanctuary set about 500m behind the busy shopping district of Admiralty on Hong Kong Island. It is set right behind the HSBC "Coat-hanger" building, so is easy to navigate to. I often used to escape here on the way home from work and indulge in some photography. Not a Must-Do while in HK, but if you are based in or around Admiralty, then check it out!
Nice green lung. Nice escape from the hustle and bustle of this thriving city. Not horribly extensive but worth a walk through and/or some people watching while giving your feet a rest.
Vacation. This park is crowded most weekends especially people with families and friends. They brought food and made this place as picnic grounds.

Worth a visit. Definitely worth a walk through this park amongst the highrise buildings of Hong Kong. Peaceful ponds with big goldfish and turtles. The gardens are lush and refreshing. Check out the avery which is free admission.

Outstanding. I arrived in the park late late at about 5pm but still managed to get some amazing photos. If theres another chance i would definitely go back to this place as ive seen only like 10% of the entire park

A Green Space Where You Need it Most. This park is on the border between Central and Admiralty. Central is an especially dense part of the city. At times, you get the feeling of too little sidewalk, too many people. This sizable chunk of green nice to see and be in. You are almost surrounded by busy streets, Cotton Tree Dr. is one of the main ways to access the mid levels. If you need a break, or are traveling with kids, this is one handy park.

Very Beautiful. Went for a stroll through the parks, and they are simply beautiful. There are a number of water features and ponds (which have fish and terrapins in). I would highly recommend going for a walk through the park or even taking a packed lunch with you, just make sure you have your camera with you.
Tranquility. A good place to relax, enjoy some Local food from small restaurants around and get energy to continue a good walk or, enjoy a Tram ride.

Simply amazing. This park really surprised me. I wasn't expecting something quiet, peaceful and full of nature in a urban jungle called Hong Kong but whoever came up with the idea, gets my vote. The way they've planned, designed and built this park right in the middle of the overcrowded city like Hong Kong is simply amazing. This park is in fact better than the ones where you have to drive miles to get away from the city but with this, one can simply walk out of the office building on a lunch break and be completely somewhere else. Superb planning and space management.
Lovely green space in centre of city. This is a lovely park right in the middle of the city where you can access Nathan Road shopping from hotels like the Royal Pacific

Lush green upscale park. A good relaxing park with good landscaping. It has got little bridge over the lake. The lake has small fishes n turtle. The chirping sounds of birds makes you feel close to the nature. Kids enjoy a lot in play area and can spend 1 to 2 hrs easily. Beautiful flowers n pleasing environment. Away from hustle and bustle life of the city.
Lovely and interesting. Well worth visiting to see the tea museum, housed in a historic building. Great to watch the terrapins 'sunbathing' on rocks in the ponds. Quite tranquil compared to 'outside'
Beautiful park to stroll through. Lovely park with ponds, butterflies and a bird avery. Worth a visit in this busy city, its a little bit of peace and quiet.

Good place to spend several hours o a stopover. This park has several places of interest.The gardens in themselves sre worth a wander, do climb the tower to take in the views.We enjoyed the Tea House Museum, especially as we had been in China earlier this year and gained a good understanding of the range of teas. The museum provides information on tea, has a wonderful array of teapots. Good that the collection of an insightful man can be displayed.

A surprising oasis in the middle of a concrete jungle. What a spectacular, beautiful and serene surprise in the middle of a concrete and glass jungle city. I was really surprised when I stepped into and explored the park - it is just lovely. You can really see how the local's use the facilities and it provides fabulous little places to stop and escape the heat and humidity. One of my favorite parts of the city.
Incredible. As a nature lover I absolutely loved this park. So many butterflies, exotic birds, beautiful flowers and fountains....
Amazing and Beautiful. This is a very Beautiful Park , Very well Maintained . The Ambience makes it sweet , and to add , it looks really natural

Aviary is special !. WE visited Hong kong park after coming down from Victoria peak through tram.. its just across the road from there ! If you have limited time.. walk straight to the aviary ....20 minute spent there will refresh you and there is not entry fee, its free.

A nice way to relax. Hong Kong is such a busy place, but this is the place to go and relax. Grab something to eat at a bakery in Admiralty go along to the park and relax. Also a couple of good museums here as well.You will forget the hustle of the city in no time.

Great break from the city. Spent a couple of hours here the other day, walking around and taking photos of the ponds and butterfly garden. Quite a lot of visitors for a week day, but still peaceful. I have yet to take a look at the zoo or observatory so I'll be coming back!

Take a break in the park.. You can walk through the park to the Victoria Peak Tram station. By this way, you'll see the great view of the tall buildings of the city. Their Bank Buildings are very interesting. And there is one view in the park, you really need to take a picture.

Four days in Hong Kong . We visited here while my husband was in the queue for the peak tram tickets. Just across the waiting area. The garden is built on a foothill and you have to make your way up a considerable gradient. They have a children's play area and an aviary and an observation tower and lots of dense vegetation giving you a jungle like feel.

A good family outing place. Hong Kong Park is a good place for you to spend half a day there with kids. The fish pond, green house, large bird cage, Olympic atrium, tea museum, art meseum, sand pit, playground etc all these facilities are free of charge.

City park - small escape from the hustle & bustle. There's an aviary with a good selection of small birds from around the region - nice break after deciding not to join the long queue for the Peak Tram.

You must stop by here !. HK park is a stunning central HK area - which must be added to any itinerary. Hidden within high rise buildings, this park has an array of wildlife living within. Turtles, coy carp and birdlife in abundance.On a sunny day, take a slow stroll through the park and soak up the relaxed atmosphere.Enjoy.
Superb. Right in the heart of the city. Wonderful place to sit and relax those tired feet. Wild life is lovely. Particularly thrilled to see so many dragonflies

Nice place in the city to get away from the city. This park is on a hillside. A good place to relax with the butterflies, birds, and water features. There is a small lake, fountains, and flowing water to calm the mind. There is a bird aviary, kept very clean by attendants mopping and wiping the bird droppings. There are playgrounds with padded surfaces.

Great for kids . We wanted to get out of the craziness of the city, so we grabbed some food to have a picnic at the park. Even when we were not able to find a nice grassy area to do so, we sat down at the Olympic area and had a nice peaceful lunch there. The gardens are beautiful and such a peaceful getaway in the city.

Beautiful park in the centre. Beautifully maintained huge park in the centre of HK island nice just to sit and relax after the hustle of the city! Tranquil after a day,s walking it's near the bus stop to get to Victoria,s Peak so we sat and rested a while.

Good looking park!. We passed this park on our way to victoria peak tram. It's a very nice park with fountains. It's worth a visit since it's right next to the tram and everybody wants to go to victoria peak so you can just go for a stroll in the park after!
Nice park. Small garden but with beautiful and some unique architecture.walkaway to the peak.good place to take picture
Take a breath between skyscrapers.. Very good place for relax during a walk between skyscrapers. Watch many kinds of birds and flowers..

Nice park in city center. This is a nice park in the center of Hong Kong. It is the base for the tram and the path going to the top of Victoria Peak. Good place to just wonder around and enjoy the water and greenery. ENJOY!
Visit after a trip to The Peak. We found the park quite by accident after taking the tram back from The Peak - a pleasant green area close to the terminus with a walk through aviary
A great break from the city. I enjoyed my walk through the park - the aviary, the thai chi area, the lake, etc. Definitely worth a stroll through on a sunny afternoon.
So much green in the city. Beautiful area in the middle of Hong Kong, there is a lovely Japanese restaurant in the middle and a bird avery which is free. I really enjoyed my half day spent there.

Lovely Escape. Hong Kong Park is a lovely, serene escape from the city - even though you are smack in the middle of the city! The waterfalls, the flowers, the lush landscaping, the turtles, the butterflies -- all offer an oasis away from the hectic city life. And the views - beautiful city-scape views abound.Don't listen to your concierge if they tell you "it's just a garden" - as ours did. I truly enjoyed the park and think it's worth a visit.

Beautiful park in the center of Hong Kong. I was very impressed by how much they've been able to fit into this park. It is actually not all that big in terms of size, but there is a ton to see/do inside, without it feeling crowded. A very nice place to spend a couple of hours and get away from the city, all while being right in the center of it!

I love this place!. The beauty of this park, the atmosphere.. This park is worth a visit. From the moment I walked into this park, I felt really calm and relaxed. If you need time for yourself or you just want to escape from the hectic city center, this place is perfect.I must say that this park is easy to find; there are a lot of signs that direct you to the park.

Animals and Plants. It's not a special place, but if you are really into zoology or animals or stuffs like that then It's a really good place to go.
It has 2 museums inside , tells you how plants and animals survive in that kind of atmosphere...

the wonders of Hong Kong Park. the walk through the park into the hot house areas and the aviary were amazing. we walked through the Tai Chi Garden where a number of people were doing tai Chi routines. The park was peaceful and interesting. On our way out couples were getting married at a marriage registry situated in the spark.

It's right be the Peak Tram so no excuse for missing it!. This is a lovely if quite small scale park which provides a welcome oasis of calm in a frenetic city. We took a stroll through it after our trip to The Peak and very much enjoyed the experience. It is free, so you've no excuse not to go!

Surprising park tcked away in Admiralty.. This park is tucked away near Shangri La Island and Marriot. It is small, but a lovely retreat from the city. Nice waterfall, ponds with basking terrapins, and a fine colonial building housing, ironically, a Chinese tea museum. Not your cup of...? It's free, and interesting.

An Oasis in the middle of a built up city. We loved this park, its beautifully kept with lots of interest, butterflies, fish, terrapins and loads of beautiful plants and fountains. Its a sanctuary !! There was a real buzz at the weekends with a craft market. Worth a visit.

Compact yet tranquil. We visited Hong Kong Park a couple of times as it was quite fascinating. The first time we passed through on the way to the Peak Tram. There are ponds with huge fish and turtles, rivers, and fountains. The park is very peaceful despite it being well used and quite small for the attractions that it fits in.There is both an indoor and outdoor aviary, a hot house and a tea museum. There is a lovely garden area with a monument to victims of SARS ; in this garden there is a tower which you can climb. This has wonderful views of the city; it also has two sets of stairs, one for up and another for down. I must say that this was ignored by some visitors. If you just want somewhere to sit quietly and watch the world go by or visit low key bird or flower exhibits, you could do worse than visiting Hong Kong Park.
Green lung in kowloon. Go go , check the flamingos and have a drink at the kiosk or wait for the people to arrive at the mosk... Have a short siesta by the waters, fountains, etc
Lovely oasis of calm in the city. Really nice park that is an oasis of calm amid the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. There's a nice playground at one end.

Oasis in the city. Great little park bang smack in the heart of Hong Kong. great escape from the office for lunch especially during the milder months of the year for a comfortable visit. They have a nice pond with lots of Koi Carp, a nice small water fall and a large bird sanctuary where the birds come quite close.

Great way to spend 2 hours in HK outside with kids. Excellent park - lots to see and experience especially if you have kids. Close also to peak Tram so after the park you can walk over and tram up to the Peak. Good cafes and great places to enjoy yourself in the park.

Solace in the centre of the city. So peaceful and attractive. The park was tranquil and really enjoyable to see other inhabitants of the city enjoying the space. views were great and aviary also very fun to see and walk round.
Charming. Lovely little oasis in such a busy city with minimal greenery. Nicely designed in a relatively compact area with good landscaping and a nice blend of greenery and water. Well worth a visit.
Good, but don't go out of your way to see it.. A cute urban park to visit on your way to the Victoria Peak tramline. If you're not hanging out in the area, don't go out of your way to see it.

go in the day. I went in the night as I wanted to experience the urban park in the dark. Oh my, I didn't see anything except a couple making out at the top of the cliff. Park was not well lit in the night, I couldn't even see the lake. I don't think anyone will be interested to visit this place in the dark, unless you want to be alone with your partner and want a romantic spot. Because besides that, there is really nothing do as the aviaries will be closed. There is a restaurant still opened though. My friend and I walked from Central MTR, onto Battery Path, passing by the Cathedral and cheung Kong Park. Long route, but it was interesting to visit it at night. Foreigners selling handbags, shirts along the way. You can even see the skyscrapers. Shorter route would be from Admiralty MTR.
Good Play Area. There is a lovely large playing area where one can take their children. Also the aviary is delightful in every sense. A good long walk to reach as well if staying at Central.

Rare public space. There are not a lot of parks close to the central part of Hong Kong island, and this probably explains the popularity of Hong Kong Park. Plenty of people walking around and enjoying the green corridor in this very densely populated city. Makes for an interesting walk from Admiralty MTR through to the Peak Tram (although be prepared for some hard core queues once you get there!)

Lovely Green Oasis. A lovely and cool refuge from the busy streets of the city. I didn't anticipate to enjoy a day at a park so much! Put aside a couple of hours to meander through- there's a lovely tea museum, aviary and conservatory all with free admission and plenty of shady benches to park yourself under and watch the world bustle by
wonderful park. its really 1 of the cool places in hong kong,its like u live in different times zones where u can enjoy the modern life style combined with nature beauty,recommended to visit .

aviary. After going to the peak we went to the aviary at Hong Kong Park. It was one of the most favorite places we have ever been. You walk into the aviary with all the amazing birds around you.You are in there enviroment. A big green parrot jumped on my husband and nibbled on his backpack, didn't want to get off. Great fun.

Oasis of calm. You would never believe you are in the middle of a bustling city. Fantastic for photographs. Start here and work your way to the Zoological Gardens. Both attractions are free and so worth a visit. From the Zoological Gardens you can exit for the Peak Tram. All 3 are in very close proximity and allow 3 - 4 hours to visit them all.

Great Park in the middle of Hong Kong. Found this whilst waiting to go to the Peak as it is near the entrance of the tram. Really green and lush and perfect for a stroll around in to get away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Well worth a visit

Hong Kong Park. Discovered by accident on the way to the Peak tram. A beautiful park in the centre of all the hustle and bustle of the main island. Well laid out and lots on offer to experience. Good attraction for families and free which is unusual.

So nice green area inside Koowloon. I like it so much, it's little not a big park but you can pass trough when you wanna go from Tsim Sha Tsui to Temple Market it is nice walk. Inside there is a corner where people use to train at Tai Chi. Nice to see
See the park on your way to/from The Peak Tram. This urban park is centrally located, and is easy to swing through on your day exploring this area of Hong Kong.

Fun place for kids and adults!. The park is quite big and it has different attractions. There is a Tea museum a huge bird cage a playground and different animals you can visit. It is a kid friendly place with restrooms and water fountains. There is no entrance fee and it is just a nice brake from the loud and busy city.

Nice place to hear the birds. Nice place to hear the birds in the middle of the bustling business center. Lots of areas to walk and rest too. One caution though, the steps can sometime get too steep. Make sure you're in for the climb. Don't forget the bird sanctuary. The best finale.

Great park situated between Central and Admiralty. Great park to walk around with plenty of ponds, a large waterfall with restaurant next to it. A small climb up the hill takes you to a number of aviaries which are very nice as well as a viewing tower. Great views of HK all for free. Plus even had free wifi

Peaceful Place. Hong Kong Park is a peaceful place to walk with the Edward Youde Aviary being an open environment for viewers to be immersed with many different kinds of birds. A conservatory with tropical and desert plants was interesting. Huge trees were along the pathways and a large fountain area was impressive. We ate fabulous food for lunch at the vegetarian tea house called "Lockcha" with a pot of specialty green tea. Lovely spot!

A green lung in the city. Such a peaceful place with fountains and a waterfall sculpture. Calming lake with fish and a wide variety of birds sharing the serenity of the place. An excellent photo opportunity for newly weds as it is next to Cotton Tree registry Office. A stay at Island Shangri-La Hotel would complete the experience!

Peaceful park in the middle of the city. Sometimes you just need to get away from the crowds and take a break. I found this park on the map and couldn't believe the pictures, so I had to go there myself. Sure enough, it is a beautiful park with trees, flowers, and wide paths. People there in the morning were sitting quietly or exercising. Once the McDonald's Cafe (!!) opened, there was a crowd there to get coffee.I had a nice walk around the first day and made it part of my trip to the train station each morning. It was much better than walking along the street the whole time.

This is the coolest place in Hong Kong!. I broke away from my friends to visit this remarkable place on my own, and am soooo glad I did. The walk-thru free-flight aviary is amazing, with elevated walkways that get you up really close to perching birds of many varieties, with the added bonus of having excellent English-language signage throughout. The Park also has a great playground area, where you can see families with their young children at play. There is a rather large pond, with koi and fountains. The Park itself covers several city blocks, and is all in all a totally delightful respite from the City's bustle. And it's 100% free!

a suprise haven. We stayed across the street from here and were given directions through the park to the tram. Ended up walking through the park most days as we found it so relaxing and calming. Its a favourite for wedding photos, so we saw lots of happy couples, and the bird avery was also a pleasant suprise.
A quiet Oasis amid the skyscrapers. This is a lovely park. Beautiful gardens with lots of colours and man made lakes and fountains. Has a great bird aviary to walk through. A highlite for us.
A quiet spot. Recommended to me by family member. Wonderful aviary, interesting plants, shrubs and trees and water features - near to peak tram

Urban Oasis. Hong Kong is one of the world's busiest and most populated cities. Hong Kong Park is exactly located at the Hong Kong city center, surrounded by skyscrapers. It is a rare but lovely oasis on the concrete jungle. Free admission. I enjoy a lunch time walk in the garden on a sunny day as it is the best way to wind down after busy work. Inside the Park, there are a lake and waterfall, garden, fountains and restaurant and it also houses the Flagstaff House Museum of Tea Ware and Visual Arts Centre, etc. It is a good place to take a short break to refresh and recharge after work or shopping!

nice garden in a busy business district. full of nice flowers inside a metropolitan.there is a green house for different kind of flowers throughout the year.there is a big bird cage for you to see different kind of birds within a very close distance.Nice place for taking photos of flowers, birds, waterfall.you can take snapshot for those who got married there because the registry of marriage is just besides the park.enjoy and take a deep breath there!

In the eyes of the beholder. Two thoughts on this location. I was not overly impressed from a Western culture perspective. On the other hand it is rare to find green space in Hong Kong so this offers the locals an enjoyable place to retreat to with their families.
Beautiful Scenery. Lovely views and peaceful surroundings. It is a great experience and would advise you see it when in Hong Kong

Paradise in the business center. The green in the middle of the skyscrapers is awesome. We visited the bird cages and the tropical plants. Don't miss it, it's a great time to be in a green scenic space surrounded by the modern and huge buildings.

Fabulous oassis amongst the high rise. We almost stumbled upon this wonderful parkland by accident. So many trees waterfalls ponds and green space, plus a conservatory all so close to the bustle of a major metropolis.

Breath!. Dear friends,
I don't know if you have had the same feeling of claustrophoby that I have experienced sometimes while walking in the streets of this city.. just in case, this is a good escape, rigth in the center of the most cahotic part of Hong Kong.

Nice find in HK. We saw many wild birds and it was a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city. We enjoyed our time here and was a highlight of our time here in HK. It is free to enter and is nice to walk around and escape

A wonderful place to visit - and for free!. Please allow several hours minimum to visit Hong Kong park, including the Aviary and the Conservatory. Amazingly this entire attraction is free to visit. The park is great to wander around and is a beautiful green space amidst the high rise buildings. The park is well laid out and has nice fountains and a large pond with lots of fish and turtles. It is not unusual to see university graduates or wedding parties having their photos taken in the park. The Museum of Teaware is also located at the park perimeter and is a great free atttraction to visit on a rainy day. There is a caged bird display area of Hornbills and other species of birds from Malaysia as well as the Edward Youde Aviary which is open from 9am to 5pm daily. The Aviary has a raised walkway that allows visitors to walk through a tree canopy from where the many species of birds can be seen and photographed. The walkway through the aviary is also wheelchair/baby stroller accessible. The valley floor of the aviary has a stream bed full of trees and shrubs, adorned with shallow pools and waterfalls, providiing visitors with many opportunities to see the many species of birds. Display panels showing illustrations of the many bird species are provided along the length of the walkway to aid in identification of the bird species. The conservatory is a big enclosure with a number of display areas of many different species of plants. It is well laid out and also worth a visit. Allow a minumim of a couple of hours to be able to enjoy this free recreational opportunity of Hong Kong Park. The park is also a nice place to enjoy your picnic lunch as there are numerous benches provided along the paths through the park.

Nice park. The park is small, but very beautiful. Have a few fountains. Near to the metro station Central. In HK a lot of small parks like this one. In the center of the city. Very clean, and nice to spend free time.
Relaxing. Fun park in Hong Kong, can recommend it to visit or just walk though to do something different from the buildings.
very pretty. A must do on your itinerary. An oasis among the high-rises. Stop off at the water and view the turtles/tortoises

Green oasis in the heart of the city. This park is an enjoyable place to visit with plenty of lush greenery and a nice collection of animals. My son especially liked the various species of monkeys exhibited.

Beautiful . What an amazing place. The grounds are perfectly maintained with hundreds of plant species to ogle if you enjoy that sort of thing (which I do!!). There is a beautiful aviary to walk through with a raised walkway that lets you watch birds flying around. They also have some gorgeous hornbills! Definitely worth a visit. Lots of play equipment for little ones too.
Beautifully mainted gardens...... Another must see when in Hong Kong. We visited this beautifully maintained Park with its huge aviary on our way back from the Victoria Peak Tram visit.
relaxing park. An oase in Hong Kong, i used it to run, but you can go and look at the Flamingos, the people that make yoga, buy a ice etc...

Pretty and relaxing park. The park itself isnt too big but the location is quite special. Having a nice, relaxing park in the middle of busy Hong Kong, surrounded by countless skyscrapers is quite unique. Its a little oasis to step into the park and getting away from always busy and fast street life. Great to have a stroll or taking a break and relax in peace before joining back Hong Kongs hectic lifestyle.
One of the landmark. Very modern park. Birds, plants, sports center, museums, artificial waterfall & water pool. Many old churches & buildings close by.
Time to rest after a busy shop. This park is a beautiful oasis in the midst of the skyscrapers and a nice place to rest after hours of shopping. Beautiful exotic plants. Thoroughly recommend
Peaceful park. Walked through here to get to the Peak Tram, nice surprise, lovely ponds with tortoises, fish. Lovely plants and trees, very well done.
Beautiful park in the city. Hong Kong Park is a lovely park in the midst of concrete and high rises. It is nicely laid out with numerous trees, water features, and paths.
free zoo, must go if you love nature. it is like a big park and zoo with many animal. the point is it is free. location, great to arrive by metro station of Admiralty.
Nice park, worth walking through to Peak Tram. Nice park to wander through on your way to the Peak Tram. Has a nice view point as well but many steps to go up.
Small Park. A small park. Nothing much there. It is good if you want to have a short rest after coming down from Peak Tram.
Clean Park! Relaxing views :). I love this park! it's clean :) i think they always sanitize their park in HK. And aside from being clean, the views are relaxing too :)

Great for young kids. We visited Hong Kong Park quite by accident - we had gone to Lock Cha Tea House and post that decided to take a stroll around the area. We ended up covering the entire park & we were glad we did! The Hong Kong Park is fairly big and is located in the middle of the city on the Hong Kong Main Island. The Park has a lot to offer for the kids - with a reasonably sized aviary, nice quiet lakes and even a small water fall. It also has a conservatory with 3 different climatic conditions - Dry, Humid & the display plant house. Fantastic for kids to learn about various birds & plant life. It also has a reasonably sized play area for the kids. The entire park is stroller friendly, though I must warn that it is quite a bit of exercise for us parents to push them up & down the park. Bottom line: HK park is a mirage in the middle of the city, a miniature version of the Central Park, though built on a hill. A great place to spend half a day or so there.
1 of the best parks in HKG. frankly,its very cool place,i visited in last january during winter season .its very good place 2 spend relaxing moments .

Some Serenity Amongst the Hustle Bustle of Hong Kong. There is a sense of tranquility in this green space in the middle of Hong Kong. I love going there and finding a bench to sit and read. It is a beautiful oasis and highly recommend a visit...but stay for a little while and experience the sights And sounds.

Worth A Visit. Only a short walk from Statue Square in central Hong Kong.
It is an attractive and lush small park in central Hong Kong surrounded by high rises. Not something that is see in too many places.
It is a good relaxing spot with lots of benches.
Lovely . A nice and green place in the middle of a crowded city. A really nice place to walk an hour or 2. Or to have a picnic. You can also visit the aviary for free

Hidden Oasis of Calm. This oasis is known to the local business community of Central and Admiralty but it seems not by many others. It has fountains, water garden, lake with ducks, lots of interesting flowers and trees, tea rooms and old restored barrack rooms. A great place to relax or to walk through on your way to meetings in the business district or with the judiciary!

Nothing special ! . I found the park rather boring. If you love birds, then maybe yes. Otherwise, feel free to skip! You are not missing out. The park was on my way to the peak so I stopped over. More to see at the Peak.

Paradise in a concrete jungle. Paradise in the midst of a concrete jungle. This is a beautifully laid out park with a pond and a hidden greenhouse. To get to this park, the best way is through Admiralty's Pacific Place - take the escalators up on the second floor of the mall, cross the road and you'll find the park's entrance. To get to the hidden greenhouse, head uphill and follow the signs. You can actually reach the visual arts centre, a small gallery displaying local artists' work, by following a path (signs show route) and it could be a nice resting spot (there's air conditioning!). My favourite part of the park is being able to see all the tall buildings surrounding it, while being surrounded by green.
great view and very good service.. The location is one of the best , the rooms are clean and almost bis 23/30 sqm totally renovated.the service is perfect but is a little expensive
Scenic place. This park captures the natural landscape in the busy and crowd business centre and also provides a relaxing environment. The aviary here is an attraction for tourists.

Cool place to enjoy the peace. This is easy to find, just follow all the escalators up. Worth a look at the gardens, ponds & wildlife. Fish, Turtles & dragonflys. Well behaved water birds. Easy ramps for disabled. Water fountains, peaceful reflection pools. On a hot day, this is so cool with the shade, water and peace.

Away from the noise and buildings. This is a nice place to go to escape the high rise buildings. It is like stepping back in time, since the old Admiralty Building is still there. There are beautiful fish and a little waterfall. A nice find. A bit hot in the middle of summer.

Hidden gem in the middle of Hong Kong city. Very pretty park right in the middle of the city. A lovely waterfall and turtles and fishes - very pretty. There is also a zoological centre nearby but didn't get a chance to visit.
Free and worth a walk through. Great for the locals to enjoy - but don't be deceived with the name. This park is 100% concrete with a huge swimming pool complex.

A lovely little park, take a visit to the Tea Museum and Cafe.. Beautiful park, can be busy, especially with couples having there wedding photos there - which is fun too! Certainly worth a walk through to take a break from building!
Conveniently located in Admiralty. Very conveniently located in Admiralty. A well maintened park, within short walk to the Peak Tram Station on foot.

Well worth finding. One side of the garden is close to the Tram station to the Peak and the other side is close to Admiralty MTR.Lakes, waterfalls, fountains and a free aviary, what are you waiting for, go!!The aviary has some of the most gorgeous birds flying around in a massive netted area with a wooden walkway through the sky as the birds fly all around, enchanting.The park is a delightful way to spend a couple of hours when needing to recharge the batteries.
Free entry. It's a free entry park...Inside the park you can also find the registry of marriage office for hongkong's citizen

A pleasant park. Hong Kong Park is a lovely park very close to The Island Shangri-la Hotel. It has fountains and lots of different kinds of fish and is a pleasure to walk through.You can cut through this park to reach the Peak Tram entrance - just follow the signs.

HK has relaxing spots and still great trees and windy paths!. I came from church at HK Union on Kennedy Rd then walked to HK Park stopping at Visual Arts Museum, people gathering on Sunday to converse, chat, saw playground with kids and parents. Ambled all the way down to ground level. thenj took tram to Western market, then to IFC..all doable and interesting. Didn't go to botannical or aviary though.

Lovely place for a walk with some nice attractions. The park itself is very nice as far as parks go, not massive but quite spacious in the middle of a busy district of the city. The things that make it stand out for me are the aviary and the tea museum. The aviary is not massive but large enough to spend just under an hour (or longer if you're a serious twitcher) observing some remarkable bird species. The park itself has a lovely variety of birdlife from the local fauna, including bulbuls and parakeets.The tea museum is a wonderful tribute to the history of tea, the process of making tea and different varieties, as well as having a great (though slightly pricey) tea shop within the museum.

Good place for kids and elders to enjoy morning and evening.. Was staying exactly opposite to garden , its in the heart of the city but once you enter inside you feel as if you have come to some country side, it has good park and games for small childrens and small birds sanctuary , a big swimming pool and a mac d inside the park .Nice palce to stroll in the evening .
a nice green oasis. Nestled in between the many highrise buildings between the mid- levels ... refreshing, with ponds, turtles and plenty of shadows ...
Take a break. Relaxing atmosphere on your way to peak... beautiful little gardens in the middle of majestic towers...
Nice stop on the way to the Peak. Nice little park in the middle of busy city. Aviary was really great with many species to watch and photograph. Free access too.

beautiful city gardens. An Oasis in the middle of this busy city with lovely ponds that join up to create a massive and very pretty water feature, complete with terrapins and fish. There is also an aviary and the gardens provide lush greenery and relief from the humidity

Welcome sanctuary. Any place like this is a nice respite from the urban bustle of Hong Kong, just for a while. This is a nice haven from it. Well kept and managed. Not a fan of aviaries though - birds should be free, not caged.
beautiful. small but beautiful. its a moment of clam in this busy and dirty city. the wildlife are wonderful to look at and the park is very well kept.

Visit to Hong Kong. The name "Hong Kong" is an approximate phonetic rendering of the pronunciation of the spoken Cantonese or Hakka name 香港, meaning "Fragrant Harbour".[31] Before 1842, the name referred to a small inlet—now Aberdeen Harbour (香港仔 hoeng1gong2 zai2, or Hiong1gong3zai3[9] in Hong Kong Hakka, literally means "Little Hong Kong")—between Aberdeen Island and the south side of Hong Kong Island, which was one of the first points of contact between British sailors and local fishermen.[32]The reference to fragrance may refer to the sweet taste of the harbour's fresh water estuarine influx of the Pearl River, or to the incense from factories, lining the coast to the north of Kowloon, which was stored near Aberdeen Harbour for export before the development of the Victoria Harbour.[31]In 1842, the Treaty of Nanking was signed and the name, Hong Kong, was first recorded on official documents to encompass the entirety of the island.[33]The name had often been written as the single word Hongkong until the government adopted the current form in 1926.[34] Nevertheless, a number of century-old institutions still retain the single-word form, such as the Hongkong Post, Hongkong Electric and the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation.
Peaceful Respite. Hong Kong Park is Hong Kong's Central Park. Although Hong Kong Park is not as big, it does have a nice aviary for bird enthusiasts.
Don't step on the grass!. Interesting to see and walk around but it's the sort of park where all forms of fun are banned, right down to even straying off the concrete onto the grass

Very relaxing. A great place to eat your takeout at lunch. A gentle stroll thro the gardens and past the koi pond sets you up for the rest of the day. Lots to see for the amateur photographer, and usually a bride or two having her photos taken

A surprising discovery, amongst the concrete and glass, and to be relished.. Hidden behind a court complex, and somewhat up the hill, is this well laid out and surprisingly large park. It is probably necessarily formally laid out, but still provides greenery in the city. There are a number of catering outlets within it.It is said that Flagstaff House, formerly the home of the British Army GOC, is the oldest western building in Hong Kong, in which case it is presumably the oldest building in Hong Kong. It is tucked away in this park, now serving another function but worth seeing.
BEAUTIFUL place to see. We visited in the pouring rain. It was a wonderful way to get over jetlag. Very beautiful and serene. Dont miss the bird sanctuary its so lovely.

Greenery in the City. This place is very relaxing and a heaven for Photographers.I really make sure that we visit this park on the way to the Peak Tram station.Very nice views seeing the trees, ponds and gardens surrounded by hugebuildings. You can even see real turtles at the top of the rocks.I suggest you visit this park for atleast 30 mins before going to the Tram station.Its a 10-15 walk from the Admiralty station,take the Tamar St. going to Queensway St. cross the road by footbridge.You either choose going there up through the escalators besides High Courts building or just walk on the left side of the road going to the Tram.No entrance fee required.Don't take too long there if you're planning to take the Tram to the Peakas queue in the tram is too much.Perfect time we went there last January as the weather was cold.
It's hot & super humid. It's hot & super humid, so there is little reason to spend much time in the park. There is an interesting metal netting hosing local flora and birds.

hidden gem. An unexpected place to relax in the busy city. One of my favourite places to take the children when we lived in Hong Kong. The Thai restaurant in the park is really a great place to stop for lunch.

Green lung of Central. It is a lovely park over 8 hectares. Beautiful facilities for kids. I recalled we took our kids when they were toddlers. There is a great aviary, a duck pond, historic buildings and fountains. The park is built across levels and as you move up, you get a great view. It is accessible from many different points and through various modes of transport. Unimaginable such an oasis can exist in the middle of a concrete jungle.

Little Oasis in the Skyscraper dessert. Great place to take an after lunch / dinner walk. It's just next to Pacific Place. A great escape from the city hush. There's a cute "teahouse" fountain for some extra fun.

Oasis in the Middle of a Concrete Jungle. I wish I had more time to sit and relax here than just past through. It was clean and a nice repose to the busy life in HK. Very clean, no funny smells around the park. Nice place to bring the stroller or a loved one. Flora and fauna in the middle of the bustling business district.

Very Beautiful. I have experienced many beautiful parks around the world. The Hong Kong Park is without a doubt one of the finest I have ever seen. With its' ponds full of fish, many birds and even a waterfall - it should not be missed. A great place to pick up some food and come here to enjoy.

Oasis among the concrete jungle. Oasis among the concrete jungle of skyscrapers in the Central area and admiralty. Waterfalls and plants make the air around to be comfortable, especially in times of intense heat. It is a place to enjoy lunch while looking off fatigue and bustle at the head offices of business in Hong Kong in the lunch break. Very close to the lower terminus stations, Tram to Victoria Peak.
Hong Kong Park Beautiful Walk. It Was Lovely Walking through the Park on a hot day there was plenty of Shady Trees to rest under the big pond had carp fish in there very clean as well

Absolutely Love This Gorgeous Place. We 打包-ed took away some food nearby and went to the park for a place to eat.We found out there was actually much to see. After finishing our meal at one of he benches, we walked around the ponds and even caught site of the waterfall.This park is breezy and a good place to get away from the heat with ample shelter from the sun. Gorgeous!
Oasis in a huge hectiv city. A very quiet and calm place to walk. Free high speed wifi. Ponds with fish and lots of birds make you feel like in oasis.
The water features are sooo pretty. There are a lot of them and the park is extremely well up kept, a very tranquil place and was a relief from the hustle & bustle of the streets...

A beautiful green space in the heart of the city. I have fond memories of HK park having got married there in the registry office in 1996 and I always make a visit there when I'm in HK. It's such a beautifully laid out and well maintained park with the fountains, gardens, ponds, aviary etc and the photo ops of the China Bank and other buildings peeping through gaps in the trees make for some great shots for photographers who can also shoot fauna and flora there. It is hilly in parts if you explore it all but it's easy accessibility from Pacific place means there's always a cool aircon recovery not far away for afterwards! From the many times I have visited this park over the years I can say that it has always been well maintained and is a rare constant in a city where cahnge and development is the norm.

A green oasis in Central Hong Kong. I take my kids there on occasions so they can also visit the adjacent zoo; yes there is a zoo in the middle of Central Hong Kong. They love it as its a truly green oasis in Central and plenty of trees too!

Great place for kids (and parents). Lots to see here, we typically start w a visit to the tea house, then lunch in the restaurant (tip: try to get a table at the back w big window next to waterfall), food is Asian and decent though portions tend to be on the small side. After lunch we let the kids run around the lake and enjoy walking behind and above the waterfall. We slowly make our way UP to the aviary (tip: while paths abound so stroller and scooter are welcome, it is a steep path up for a few minutes) which is honestly the best in HK w lots of different birds flying around freely. Several locals come here to paint .... Finally we go to the playgrounds yes w a s as its several playgrounds on various levels depending on age. Lots of fun though not the easiest to supervise if like me u have several kids spanning 2-8 years old!
good afternoon out. We picnicked, watched the bugs, saw some fish, watched birds in the park and at the Aviary, and played at the multi level playground.

A delight!. I love this park. There is such a variety of things to see as well as being a beautifully maintained botanical garden in the heart of the city! The conservatory and the aviaries are well-worth visiting. Spend some time in the tea house, too.

Another gem in the city. This park is surrounded by many tall buildings/offices. I love the small aviary park inside this park where some colourful birds were spotted. Again, this park was clean and well maintained during my visit. No fee is required and you can buy some snacks in the park itself. No need to worry about the heat as free water dispenser is everywhere.I just wish my country could have this kind of high standard free park...XP
A surprising oasis in a concrete jungle. Beautiful tranquil park above the hustle and bustle of the city. Lovely restaurant in the centre of the park was a great way to cool down on a very hot day.
fresh air in the city. very large park just back from the riverfront. gentle strolling and watch the locals at their exercises
A pleasant afternoon. A lovely place to walk around but got a few beastie bites. The aviary was a great experience and the water features were good. The restaurant was also pretty decent.

Lovely Park. This park located on the property of Flagstaff House offers an oasis in the middle of a busy downtown. The park is not large but contains Flagstaff Tea Museum and a beautifully landscaped park complete with water features and ponds. Children will particularly enjoy the large gold fish and hundreds of turtles that live there. There is also a Memorial and statue to a Canadian soldier Robert John Osborne from Winnepeg who was part of the Canadian Corps of 2000 soldiers posted in Hong Kong during WW2. He won the Victoria Cross in Hong Kong.
The english names and signs. So nice and quiet to step into from the hussle and bustle of hong kong. Not many people there is the weekdays and alot cooler than walking on the streets.
Parrot loves cameras. The parrot you can see among the pictures - it just loves people to take pictures of it. If you are in the Hong Kong Park - do not miss the aviary!

Shifu Wong. Hong Kong Park is a good garden to relax and picnic in the conjested Hongkong City, especially at every weekends you can see a lot of foreigners are hanging around in the peaceful greenish garden just to lie down and doing picnic. Ocassionally you can see some Indonesian and Phillippino maids on the musics and slow dance beside the lake pools. It is amazing!

Interesting Green Soace. Really enjoyed visiting the aviary (600 birds we were reliably informed) and the tea museum was suprisingly interesting as if we were honest we really went in at first to escape the heat and find some air con. The gardens are very well maintained with lovely water features. Probably more appealing to a couple or a family with young children who like to wander round a large space.
If on your way while walking. Interesting park in the heart of Hong-Kong, surrounded by skyscrapers. Impressive sensation to see it, as also the waterfall inside it.

Worth a walk on your way to other places.. Lovely big park near to the centre of town (if Hong Kong had a centre). Excellent playground for kids which was well used whilst we were there. Lovely for a stroll around, and even had a water park (of sorts). More like extravagant swimming pools. Definitely worth a walk through on your way to somewhere else.
Chill out in the city centre. An important part of the green belt in Admiralty. You can visit the Museum of Teaware or just stay outdoors for the nature. Lucky ones will see pretty brides around.

Secret of HongKong. Love going to this part every time we visit HongKong. Going to the big cage of birds is something great to do with the kids of even for couples.
If you are going to go to " AT THE TOP " then I would recommend that you take a walk before or after though the park.

Take a break and see amazing comic book statues. This is the Hong Kong version of Central Park, its a place where you can get away from the endless shopping and hustle and bustle of Nathan Road. Enjoy the sculptures, birds and tortoises. Even massive pools if its too hot.

A relaxing afternoon trip. I took a stroll through this park while I was in the area. It isn't an amazing park; I believe there are better ones in Hong Kong. I loved the small lake with turtles swimming around inside. There is also a tower in the middle with a staircase leading up to a nice view. The stairs are a bit rough on a hot day, but not to bad for someone in shape. A fun visit while in the area, or I suppose for someone living in Hong Kong, would be a good place to take a date.

Love this park. We r locals and love taking our kids here. There are age appropriate playground for the smaller kiddos to enjoy without having to be wary of the older ones. Our only complaint is that there are no swings!!!

Green Oasis. A green oasis in the midst of the concrete jungle. Love the aviary and the tea museum. Beautifully landscaped grounds in the idle of Central Hing Kong. Don't miss the aviary, lots of friendly exotic birds here. See my travel blog for more details and ottos. Www.travelswithrarecat.blogspot.ca. Search for Hong Kong Park.

Tranquility in a sea of madness. This place is definitely underrated and thankfully under used. If you want to escape the hustle and bustle of the millions of people go here, you will be sure to be able to find a sheltered and peaceful spot.
Nice. Nice park,cool weather ,beautiful threes ,frowers,i been walked around and took photos.took some relax

A great start to the day!. Early morning Tai Chi in the park is a lovely way to immerse yourself and start your day. We felt very welcomed to join the group with one lovely gentleman showing us what to do
