Wonderful Aviary!. The park itself is a nicely landscaped escape in the middle of bustling Hong Kong. The aviary is definitely the highlight though with exotic birds buzzing all around and within close view. Well worth the free admission and an hour or so!

Gorgeous!. My kids LOVED running around in this park. Granted, we live in Beijing so they have not had an opportunity to run around outside for a while, but the scenery was breathtaking and we particularly enjoyed the aviary. We happened to get there at feeding time, which allowed us great, close up views of the birds. At one point my six-year old yelled "I hope Disneyland is this much fun!" I wish we'd had more time to explore the park - there is so much to see and we only scratched the surface.

A good option for a morning walk. There aren't a lot of places to escape the hustle and bustle in HK, but this is one of them. We went for a morning walk in the Park and then the nearby Zoo gardens. Not only was it nice and quiet, there were also some interesting monuments that were well explained and so it was also a bit of a tourist experience. There was a big avery, ponds and a big playground so a great place to visit if you are travelling with kids. It's easily accessible from Admiralty and Central.

Visit the aviary. It was great (and I don't even like birds). Very well done, well maintained. Clean. The walk is a tree top walk. Birds eat real fruit attached to feeding posts. Lots of beautiful colours.

Peaceful. If you want a break whilst on HK Island, this is the place. The city just doesn't stop. The lovely gardens and water pools with the enormous Koi are worth the stroll, but dont wake up those having a nap on the park benches

Good mid day break in Cnetral. Find any walkway, from tram, Pacific Place Mall...sneak through narrow walkway and steps to big bird cage and other park exhibits. An tropical oasis at Central District--there is no other in the World--tropical rain forest in midst of business district! Enjoy! Pssst! Best of World Brunch Buffet at Conrad Hotel...don't tell anyone else...my secret joint with harbor view and best of this world cuisine.

Sunday sights. After the compulsory trip on the Star Ferry we walked underneath Norman Foster's HSBC building on our way to catch the Peak Tram, with the added attraction on Sunday of literally thousands of Phillipino maids sitting out on blankets, having picnics and generally socialising with their friends. After the tram ride we stumbled into Hong Kong Park, another oasis from the traffic and hustle of HK, with a spectacular walk through aviary full of local bird species flying all around. Magical.

Nice rest from the busy streets.. This is a lovely tranquil space in the midst of the chaos of Hong Kong. Close to the peak tram station it is well worth a visit. The climb up to the entrance of the aviary (so many steps) is worth it.

Beautiful oasis!. We found this park quite by accident, it was quite busy with tourists but was tranquil at the same time. As it was inbetween Christmas and New Year there were pretty displays of red Poinsettia. We followed the park signage to the bird aviary, expecting to see a few parrots in a cage, but wow! what a surprise to find a huge walk-in aviary with a delightful array of coloured birdlife amongst a tropical rainforest! We also enjoyed the Tai Chi garden containing a poignant memorial to the SARS virus victims of 2003.The whole park was a delightful find - and free entry too!
cool breeze at night. It is best to stay here during or before sunset to enjoy the cool breeze and serenity of the place. The garden is spic and span with a lot of missionaries around =)

Nice to see a park in the middle of office buildings. I quite like the tea museum in the park. I learn quite a bit on tea and i went to the tea house to practice what i've learned. Bad thing about HK Park was having to climb the long hill up the park. Super tiring. But i guess that can't be help, given the land scarcity in HK, most inaccessible places are converted to parks / zoos since they can't be used for construction of buildings. There's also quite a lot of people taking wedding photos. Overall quite a good place to visit after a hard day at work shopping.
Great for the kids. We did enjoy our walk with our three kids in the park. A lovely Aviary to walk through, water features and a park at the top to finish. Worth a visit to give the kids some time.
Nice and cozy park. Locals seem to favour it for wedding photo sessions and lunch time breaks.Finely kept and have a lovely garden.
Do not miss the aviary.... Out of the city in the middle of the city. Go to the aviary and walk on a small bridge among exotic birds.

Lovely park in the middle of HK's urban jungle. Beautiful park - lots of interesting flora and fauna - fountains and wildlife a big hit with our 7 year old son - a lovely stroll and welcome relief from the built-up architecture, and hectic pace of life in HK - well worth a visit if you are in the area - quite small so wouldn't travel a long way unless you are looking for something specific there...

Best park in Hong Kong. Local expert have great review of this park and I like it so much also. Can see Tea musuem and nice bird place, inside have many birds you can take many good pictures. This is great place to visit.

What a delightful escape. This park was terrific. We went through it on the way to the Peak Tram but on the way back decided to have a really good walk through it. Loved the water features and the little lakes with all the fish and turtles in it. This poor little turtle tried 10 - 15 times to get up out of the water with all the fish snapping it but eventually made it! By this time quite a crowd had congregated and we all clapped when he managed it!Didn't go to the aviary but the park is immaculately clean and laid out. Just a beautiful oasis in the middle of a very busy city. Saw people just relaxing reading the paper or just chilling out. A perfect place to while away a few hours.

Bizarre expereience. Great place to escape the bustle of the City but a bizarre location between sheer rock face and soaring skyscrapers. Huge aviary with elevated walkway to observe the tropical birds. Very good Thai/Japanese restaurant and a tea museum as well!
Small park. Very small but green. Good for people working in Central district of Hong Kong to take a break or have a breathe of air.

a real surprise. We stayed at Conrad and very nearby is the Hong Kong Park converted from Victoria Barracks into a beautiful area of peace. We so enjoyed the flowers, water, conservatory, aviary (brilliant, we spent hours there seeing so many fine birds) and tea Museum in old army commander's house. And observing weddings at registry just inside park! Do go.

Very nice!. We went to the park after going up the mid level escalators and walked down through the zoological gardens and into the park. It's a great relaxing place and you can take some great park/city pictures. The Peak is also near so it is easy to cover lots of ground with this park as a nice relax in between!
beautiful. Restful and interesting haven in the centre of the island. Go see the tea museum. And then walk straight into the Pacific shopping centre.
Hong Kong Park. a good outdoor for us to have a stroll and the Children's playground for the children to run freely.
An oasis. Pick up some of the freshly prepared food at Pacific Place GReat and head to the park just up stairs. Calm, peaceful and with a fantastic view.

All you imagine by thinking of a Chinese park. A really nice park in the middle of Hong Kong Island, I enjoyed spending 2 hours in this park! The park is located in the middle of the financial district. On one side you find the Lippo Towers and a bit further you come across the tram station for The Peak.

Hong Kong park. A lovely park, built on the site of the old British Victoria garrison. Trees and water falls a-plenty. Terrapins basking in the sun on rocks, (For a terrapin basking on a rock can mean basking on another terrapin due to the lack of rock space) and some of the biggest goldfish known to man!It does get busy on a lunch time as it seems to be one of the few green area in a busy city, but well worth the visit for a few hours of relative peace and quiet. Walk by cool waters, eat an ice cream, feel the stress bleed from your body. R-E-L-A-X.

Great place to rest your feet. Parks and markets are inexpensive ways to enjoy the culture and people watch. This park is beautifully designed, offers many things to do and see, and generally easy to get to. My boyfriend and I watched locals do tai-chi, walked through the bird aviary (part of it was closed due to maintenance), and took in the architecture of nearby buildings.

a little gem in central. Available through Pacific Place/Admiralty or Central MTRsIf it's a hot day, you can cool off under the fountains. The bird sanctuary is enjoyable even if you don't know anything about birds. No grass to picnic on.Fun to see wedding photos being taken at the western end. Also a very popular place for graduation photos (which for some reason seem to be taking place almost every weekend).

Tranquil place. HK Park the is smack in the middle of Central area where office workers can take a respite from their office. On Sundays, the park is a meeting place for Filipino maids. Few of the roads around the park are closed and it becomes almost a carnival for the maids to enjoy.

Best City Park in Hong Kong. A nice relaxing park in the centre of Hong Kong. House a number of colonial buildings that have been well restored. It makes a good break from the noise and business of the city. The restaurants are a bit dissappointing, and expensive, so eat elsewhere.

Overall the park looks nice. The park is nice, espeically it is surround by all the high rise building. However, there is not any particular things that I really really like there. Still feel good walking around and enjoy the flower.
Nice peacful retreat with skyscraper backdrop.. I enjoyed strolling through here,especially liked the walk in aviary,nice and peaceful, like a little rainforest in the middle of the city.

Grab a sandwich and come for lunch. On a hot day, you can have a lovely walk in the park and walk through the fountains and behind the waterfall to keep cool. There are different greenhouses to see, and of course the aviary, not to mention the tai chi garden and the 2 ponds, full of fish and terrapins. Go to the Great supermarket in the basement of the Pacific Place supermarket, grab a drink and a sandwich, and sit in the park with your picnic. A very pleasant way to spend an afternoon.I'd give the museum of teaware a miss, unless you are a really big tea fan, as it is very small without much to see, although there are some nice teapots on show.
Nice walk-through at the base of the hills!. Walk through the park in an afternoon. There's waterfalls, Chinese decor, landmarks, high-rise views, etc. Take pictures. It's awesome!

It is green, It is clean. Well, if you visit Hong Kong it is not for nature, but the park is nice. There are some nice plants and lovely places to sit for an escape from the city. It is not very big but space is something you find in Hong Kong..
Wedding. I attended a friends wedding at Hong Kong Park. It look dirty and the wedding felt like it wasn't that great for them. But we know they were in there zone as it was there day
A relaxing stroll on rainy day. In summer the park has beautiful flowers and is a favorite spot for weedding photos but even in winter it is niceley decorated for the Christmas season.

Nice clean with many different plants turtles & carp. The green and openess in the heart of the city. You walk thru it to get to the tea museum which is a good worthwhile way to spend a couple of hours.
A small garden away. A escape from the hustle and bustle. Walk through and see the koi fish pond. The teaware museum located in here - okay. Lock Cha Tea House also located in here.
worth a walk round. very tranquil for the city centre...lovely fish, turtles and birds. plus the registry office is near here, so the chance to see the locals getting married!

The only quite spot in the city!. After having spent more than two month in HK, this park is the only place which is quite in the city!
You can sit on a bench and relax :)

Lovely. The park is tranquil and perfect to get away from the hustle an bustle of HK. We spent some time just walking around and enjoyed it immensely. There are numerous water features, turtles, a bird enclosure, cafe etc. Seeing the skyscrapers though the trees makes for some nice photos. We'd go back.
An attractive city park. A hilly walk before or after the peak tram with a large walk in aviary fully of exotic birds. The park sits like an island amid the high rises.
Paradise. Wow - what a wonderful advertisement for Hong Kong right in the heart of the island. Well manicured gardens, easy access, good water features and easy to get around.

A peaceful refuge in the midst of the high rises. This is a pleasant place to spend a bit of time in Hong Kong. There are water features which block out the sounds of traffic, etc. Lots of benches to sit on, paths to wander along. There is also a moving monument to the health care workers who died during the SARS epidemic. A foot massage walk (bring thin socks so you can really enjoy it). And a Museum of Tea. Next door to the Museum is a Gallery and Tea House. The Tea House was very peaceful. The menu for the tea was about 6 pages. I chose a tea I had learned about in the Tea Museum. A young woman came and prepared the tea at my table. Between the walk around the park and my time at the tea house, I left the park refreshed and ready to tackle the hordes again.

An Island of Tranquility. Nestled among high rise banks, hotels and shopping centers Hong Kong Park provides visitors with lush foliage, gorgeous flowers and bushes and beautifully designed water features and cascades even a large waterfall. Also included without any admission fees are a super conservatory and a very impressive and large aviary. Here serenity rules. A must visit.Bottom line: You can get there on Bus 103 from Kowloon Station or Bus 12 from the Central ferry dock. Also useful is Bus 15C from the Central ferry dock but it terminates at the Peak Tram stop after which you’ll follow signs and walk a little. But the best way is to use the escalators in Pacific Place (Exit C at Admiralty) and follow signs all the way to the top. Riding all the way.

Artificial but Hong Kong central has no green. A green oasis inthe concrete and you may be knocked over by hoardes of wedding parties and photographers, but a place to relax away from the bustle. It feels manufactured but who cares, it's green.
Pleasant. A nice retreat from busy Central. A good place to walk, chat with friends and watch children at play.

Relax or wander. Beautiful green park to relax or wander around. We had lunch at the restaurant, looking out on the pond and waterfall. We enjoyed the museum too.
The free zoo is across the road on cotton tree drive.

Staggering views at night.. The view from the Peak is unique. No where else in the world can you be on the top of a mountain and directly below you is a mass of skyscraper art, lit up like Shanghai, together with one of the world's busiest harbours all set out below you like a real life jigsaw puzzle.

garden in the city. when I visit this park it was just after chinese new year, full of flowers everywhere, Peony everywhere, so beautiful, and also there is a green house with a lot of flowers arrangement inside, made the city more green and breath more clearly, love such feeling so much! also there is a pond with tortoises, it was so much fun to see them swimming!

Beautifully arranged. The park is divided into small sections, including olympic, garden, and tai chi (where you can participate). Situated in the bustling Central area where all the businesses and high end residences are, its close to where you can pick up the Peak Tram
Great with children. Beautiful park with a good children's playground, interesting teaware museum with a tea shop & restaurant.
Oasis in the bustle of HK. Finally a bit of greenery in HK. Also visited the Tea musem which is also recommended. (It is also free :)

View the new brides in Hong Kong. In September Hong Kong park is a very warm and humid place. However the walk through the trails and vegetation make it worthwhile. Also if you are there on the weekend you will always see the new brides and grooms having their pictures taken by the fountain. Also the visit to the tea museum is fun.

Quiet Oasis (sometimes needed). It was a pleasant break from the hustle and bustle of HK to wander through the park - the large aviary was a nice place to spend some time relaxing and cooling off, and the tea museum in the historic house within the park is also worth a visit as part of a quiet time from travelling

peaceful. loved it here!!!so peaceful in a very busy city.we ate a picnic lunch here, the waterfall is stunning, lots of seating areas and grass, also a little tea museum..free of charge, grand little park :)
Gorgeous!. A beautiful park to walk through - an oasis in the city. Recommended!! Must see! Take your time then head to the Pacific Place shopping centre.
Green & Fresh. Very good park to take in some fresh air and greenery, wonderful flowers and very clean & tidy. Be sure to take a break there.

Oase in a city. Almost in the midst of the commercial centre is a very well made and preserved green park, with clever design so the park seems bigger than the reality. There is also a very interesting bird sanctuary with 650 species and a fly platform where you are on, so you can obeserve the birds on eye level. I like to rest my mind and ears in this place.

An Oasis of peace and calm. This peaceful haven was a pleasant surprise and an opportunity to sit and relax away from the bustle of people and traffic in the adjacent streets. We were surprised to see the flamingos and other water fowl in the large ponds in the centre of the park and enjoyed a walk around the gardens once we had rested our feet. The park itself was very clean and even the loos were relatively pleasant to use.

Check out the Tea Museum. A wonderful oasis in the middle of hong kong island. The star attraction for me is the team museum inside flagstaff house, which gives a detailed history of tea drinking and trading over the centuries. The best part is that it's free!

Worth a visit if you have spare time!. Hong Kong Park has excellent facilities for locals for all different sporting events. There is some nice plants and flowers but it is nothing special for a tourist the botanical gardens in Kuala Lumpar are much nicer than Hong Kong Park if you want to see stunning gardens!
Peace in pandemonium. As with all HK parks, kept very clean. Lots of water, fish ponds, snack bars, clean loos, seating areas.

Relaxing time. Very clean and well kept, the gardens everything was manicured, the bird aviaries great designed and the birds looked to be well looked after, Even the ponds looked great with the Flamingos sunning themselves, well worth the time to wonder around. Bill

Hong Kong Park--A Wonderful Place. Probably my favorite place so far in Hong Kong. It's small, so it is not overwhelming and it is beautifully laid out. There is a great fountain that you can walk in and stand behind the water. There is also a man-made waterfall that you can walk up behind and get a great overview of the park. The ponds are wonderful--stocked with koi and the best turtles I've seen. I find the butterflies to be astounding. They are large, some as black as midnight, others as colorful as a rainbow, and they will sit and let you photograph them. The plants and trees are labeled for your edification.My favorite places in the park are the Flagstaff House Museum of Tea Ware and the LockCha Tea House next door. If you love tea, the gift shop at the museum has wonderful teas as well as great tea ware. The LockCha Tea House is reminiscent of the tea houses of the early 1910's and 1920's. The waitress will come and make tea in the traditional way at your table. The restaurant is vegetarian and serves great dim sum. They also have tea tastings at the restaurant. The marriage bureau is also in the Park, and every time I've been there beautiful brides and their handsome husbands are with their bridal parties taking pictures amid the wonderful grounds. Definitely a place to bring your camera.
Pleasant diversion from city. Walking trails, flowers, birds, smells, real people watching made this a very nice antidote to the pure commercialism of Victoria Peak.

Hong Kong park is a must. With a hot house conservatory containing many different orchids, cacti and a waterfall this is a great visit on its own. Add to this the small area planted with butterfly attracting plants where you'll see large blue butterflies, orange ones and others make sure to take your camera.

Surprise. I didn't know about this one before our arrival. What a gem. Don't leave Hong Kong without seeing this park. We enjoyed the Tea Museum and the bird house. But, basically we enjoyed the whole walk in the park.

A great place to escape the hustle and bustle of HK. A great little park with a lot going for it. Lots of fountains and water make this park a great place to escape the smog and pollution for a few hours. There is a great Dim Sum restaurant in the center of the park as well

A Little Gem. This was right across the street from my hotel. It is very small and well used, but it is maintained in beautiful condition. There are a variety of things to do. Walk around the ponds and look at the fish and turtles. Visit the Tea Ware Museum for a history lesson in tea. Walk through the aviary and see and hear the birds. Sit on a bench and read.It is not large enough for a run and is also very full of people at most tiimes of day.
Great Walk. We went to this with the other garden. They are very close to each other, and have a similar feel. This garden has a great bird exhibit and also a place with plants from around the world.
Very nice outing. Right between the skyscrapers - an other world of tranquility and different atmosphere. The fish/turtles pond is beautiful. Also the conservatory and birds enclosure.

Take a few minutes to enjoy the tranquility. We loved the piece in the heart of the city. It's worth an hour just to enjoy the plants house and the bird sanctuary as well as the fountains and the park in general. We stopped and had a cool drink at the restaurant by the small fountain.
Very nice park. Relaxing and very nice park close to the center. You can take a stroll here for about an hour. We can really recommend to go here!

A oasis in a busy city. We found this wonderful park by accident and so glad we did. Its so quite when you walk in just the noise from the birds. We found the resturant inside the middle of the park and what a lovely place to eat. Very good service and a wonderful choice of food. then vist the bird avairy very interesting

A Gem in midst of buildings. What a wonderful surprise to find the garden so beautiful and well kept. The lake is full of fish, turtles with beautiful butterflies and colorful dragonflies. The Conservatory housed thousands of assorted species of dry and tropical plants while the aviary is just excellent. Make sure to stop by at the Flagstaff Teaware Museum( free admission ). A sanctuary in the middle of busy Hong Kong. Impressive !
An oasis of calm. This small park is in the middle of the city but a tranquil oasis of calm amidst all the madness of the city with skyscrapers all around......wonderful.

Don't go if you have bad knees. There were a lot of steps including up to the bird aviary so could be a problem for some people. The aviary worth a visit, and the park was nice with a nice waterfall and fountains. Nice contrast to the noise of the city, Flagstaff House museum of teaware in grounds but closed on wednesdays so we didn't see it. Passed a pleasant hour here.
Nice oasis in the concrete jungle. Waterfalls, lakes, trees, tea museum, snack stalls and plenty of space to relax and people watch. and terrapin/turtle watch too.

One of the rare green spots in the middle of the city. Located conveniently 'behind' Admiralty MTR station, it's a good place to relax and enjoy the greenery. There are a few animals here and there, but it's no zoo. Did I mention access is free?

The aviary is one of the best places in HK. This is a great park, supremely located, but the aviary is simply exceptional. I cannot imagine a stay in Hong Kong without a visit here. The entry is free.

Relaxing. Hong Kong park is a lovely little place to go and relax. You wouldn't believe you're in the middle of busy Hong Kong, with its streets packed full of cars and buses not far away.It very clean and kept well. The pond is full of koi carps and terrapins, which you'd never see in a public park back home, because you couldn't trust people not to steal them or hurt them, but here in Hong Kong, everyone seems to respect the wild life.There's even a water fall where you can walk behind it and make your way up higher into the park.

Peace in the heart of the island. This is where you can find peace if you need a breather from walking around shopping centers and busy streets in HK Central. Here you can find the bird park, the art centre (very very cool), and walk around the park shaded by massive trees.

Nice walk and rest. After leaving the Peak tram my family and I walked through Hong Kong Park. It was nice a quiet and had a large play area for the children. It was also a nice walk and a nice escape from the crowds. There is also a large aviary inside the park and many areas to just sit and enjoy the peaceful lush green park.

A very pleasant place. We walked through here during our stay in Hong Kong. A very nice and tranquil park. The kids loved the fountains and it was the perfect way for them to cool off after a long hot day of being out and about.
Relaxing. Had a pleasant stroll around the park on my last day in HK. Very relaxing and many people doing their ti-chi

Quiet and beautiful park!. We walked through this park to get to Victoria Peak tram. It is very peaceful, has a nice lake, water fountains and a great view like mostly all the places in Hong Kong.Very clean and no entrance fee.

Calm Oasis in a busy City. Nice to walk around and eat an icecream. A quiet oasis in a very busy City. Great for people watching and checking your emils (Wifi hot spot1) - you can just sit and absorb the atmosphere!

Amazing. One of the most astionishing places in Hongkong. Walking in a big park, surrounded by skyscrapers. nice to pick up on a tour from Peak tram to Pacific place and MTR admiralty station. Do not miss the free visit to the aviary where you can walk among birds on 3 levels between treetop and bottom
Beautiful park. A lovely park at great contrast to the surrounding city. A busy little place, bit peaceful all the same. Wear some insect repellent if you can.

An oasis in the city. Contrary to popular belief, HK has a lot of green spaces, which tourists don't typically know of. The HK Park is easily accessible and is a great place to get away from the hustle bustle of traffic and humans. Whilst you can't totally escape construction noise, it is still a lovely place to chill.

Lovely calm surroundings for a busy city. For a quiet reprieve from the hustle & bustle of HK, this park is a gorgeous escape. The gardens are clean & well maintained and are beautiful to enjoy to opt out of the frenetic shopping.

if you want a quiet peaceful location. then go to Hong Kong Park. Get off at Admiralty walk across to Pacific Mall , you'll love this mall then take the escalators to the park. Built by the HK Govt. it's an oasis in the middle of HK Island. We would thoroughly recommend it

Totally worth it for the bird aviary. Hong Kong can be an expensive place but this is not one of them. A totally free park that includes an awesome bird aviary. One tip-enter from the top (Kennedy Street I think) and walk down. If you dont do this you will end up walking uphill the whole time like we did. It was pretty cool because it was a park situated right in the middle of buildings. Very tranquil and totally worth a walk around if you are looking for something to do on any given day.

Green Haven Amongst Metal Giants. This park is a little sanctuary in the middle of a bustling city. Went there with a twin pram and from Admiralty Station we had to carry it up some steps (at station). The park itself has many ramp walkways so pretty easy access. We walked all the way to the children's playground up some pretty steep hills! But my girls loved it. Nice serene area with plenty of spots to sit in the shade and listen to water flowing. They have many water fountains here. Nice green break from all the city viewing!! Great place!
Disinfected 4 times a day. Loved this park. The weather was hot so i don't remember it fondly, but my kids adored the multi-level playground and it was a nice shaded walk around the place.
Nice bit of greenery in big city. Its free and there is enough to see and do for a couple of hours - Well worth a visit if you fancy a rest from shopping

The best park ever.. I went for a school project, but it was better than possibly expected. There are so many buildings, fountains and things like that. It is also very convinient to go after the Peak. Surprisingly, it was not that full and it was even better than Victoria Park. It's deinetely worth a visit.
HK park. nice place to relax, quite calming in the middle of the city with fun water-fountains, ponds, teahouse etc + close to peak-tram
Must. Must see in HK (use the Tram and share the experience, buy tickets in advance). Perfect views of HK and Kowloon.
Must visit in the morning. Many different aspects--all textbook Hong Kong Chinese. Many people playing music or doing Tai Chi. Beautiful birds and plants.

A Vast Space. Not much was happening at the park when I went there. I liked the park because it was clean, tidy and somewhere quiet to sit. I think I would like to see more activities in the park which would encourage young families to go there.

More Free Entertainment in HK. Lovely place to sit for a while or to see the many views. There is a fantastic aviary, a Tai Chi court and a Marriage Registry - on a good day you can watch a parade of brides having photos taken by the fountains. The whole thing is free and there is even free wi-fi provided. There are good loos and water fountains along with a little cabin selling snacks & drinks.

The best view over HK!. I really love this place! The tram ride is so much fun every time, and you will see the fantastic view over the city and Kowloon. The night view is more picturesque with the illumination as it is often cloudy during the day time.Absolutely recommended!

Lovely Oasis. It is a lovely in a city with so much congestion and so many high risers to have a place of greenery to relax and enjoy. You must go to the Aviary, which has a great feel and takes you away from the hussle and bussle to enjoy a walk above the trees and a look at some interesting species of birds.
the greenery was good. the unique plants was good. the place is good to come with kids . have a photo , will post..The fountain in the entrance is good . well kept park

My son loves it and so do we. If you like theme parks, it really doesn't get much better than this. Disney Land has even won over my husband who hates rides. My five year old son loves it - and what a great way to spend a day with family!This is a much more compact Disney Land and understandably so. Even then we still did quite a bit of walking, so I actually quite like the fact that it's small. I've been to the Paris one before and remember only that we had to walk miles from one attraction to the other. There are certainly things you could do to cut short some quequing time. Buy the tickets online is one of them. Otherwise you have to waste some 30 minutes to get in the park, which is a long time for little kids. They also have "fast pass" that you should try to utlise. I suggest doing a bit of homework before you go - find out which rides you would like to do, and arrange your day around them. Fireworks at 9pm is apparently really great, but for the super jet lagged people like us it was a bit too late. Save something for next time I guess! Next time we will also consider getting a 2 day pass just to take things at a more relaxing pace.This is certainly a park that is more tailored around little kids (4-7). And of course the older ones will still have a great time - go on Space Mountain and you will understand!Overall a very worthwhile spot to visit, especially if you have kids! We will be back next time!
A swath of green. There are walking paths, trees, quiet nooks and corners and it is very accessible by bus, MTR. It is free. Don't miss it.

OK for a walk away from the bustling city center. There's nothing really special about the park, but it is a nice place to have a walk and maybe have a coffee. Still, it a has a nice aviary with tropical birds and an interesting ceramics and tea bowls museum, which can be goals to go there.

Peaceful greenery in bustling Hong Kong. A peaceful escape from the concrete jungle of Hong Kong into this colonial garden, with its fountains, trees, bird aviary and the Tea Museum located in an old colonial army building that has fascinating tea pot collection and the history of tea in a way a European can newly appreciate. A culturally rich zone, located right in central HK.An easy walk to the Victoria Peak cable car.Take your walking shoes as there's not a flat piece of ground in the park.

Dont miss this one!. Not often spoken about but HK Park is a delighful oasis of greenery in the middle of the Island. Lovely gardens, waterfalls and many a bride to be seen in this popular park with the locals

Something truly special.. A (practically) deserted lavish botanical garden with fish, 10s of species of birds, terrapins and wild flowers, maintained in a location enclosed by 300m high iconic skyscrapers. The park is tranquil, clean, picturesque and has many cool features like a waterfall that you can walk behind and an observation tower to get one of the best views in the city. The contrast between nature and urban environments creates a hidden oasis that you would be mentally ill not to love.
Fresh. very central and make you really fresh when you enter. It has swimming pool that you can relax many trees. I really love it.

Nice to have a break. They called this place, botanical garden and zoo, but this is then a shrinked version of any botanical and zoos that I had the opportunity to visit in my life. Anyway, it's one of the rare refreshing place, where you'll see some non-artificial green in the city.Oh yes, as you'll discover, Hong Kong is backed by a hill, so does the park. Be clever, and start from the top to reduce the efforts.

Hidden gem in the middle of HK city. One of my favourite places that we visited on our trip! The park is huge and despite being in the middle of the city it is so quiet and peaceful! We loved the aviary the most. A beautiful place to relax and unwind. Avoid lunchtime in the park though as a lot of workers come to eat lunch here form the nearby office buildings.
OK. Offers some piece and tranquility in the middle of the bustling city, not much else to offer though.

a mini oasis in the CBD. a nice place to stop over for a sandwich (from the supermarket of qUEENSWAY plaza or city super at Pacific Place or lunch at one of the 5-star hotel nearby at the Admiralty MTR station)

Must visit specially with kids. Went throught here on the way to the Peak. Easy access from Admirality station (cross the pedestrian bridge, go through the mall and you are there). Kids enjoyed it a lot. Anything from watching the turtles in the water, plants conservatory, aviary, and just walking around the park. The jungle gym did seem to need a bit of updating/maintenance but too young for my 8 and 10 yr . old any way. The Peak lower terminus is easilly accessed after you are done so you combo this park with the Peak visit.

Oasis away from the city madness. Located in TST and right next to busy Nathan road is HK Park. My favorite destination for a calm walk. Mind that it is best done in the day time as in the evening youngsters and many of the local community gahther here.The bird sanctuary is a nice peaceful place to wander of in your thoughts, grab an ice cream cone on your way as you walk past the Swimming Pool, watch the kids play soccer in the football cages or end up near TST and hop into one of the local restaurants nearby for some traditional "Yam Cha" or so called Dim Sum...Mmmmmmmmmmm.......

Oasis in the City. This is an amazing patch of green in the middle of the city of Hong Kong. It has a zoo, waterfalls, rivers, ponds fresh air and an amazing sense of peace in the city. A must to visit.

Beautiful. My husband and I got married here almost 19 years ago so had to re-visit and bring our teenage kids - they thought it would just be a walk in the park but it was beatiful. Plenty of places to sit, the Aviary is definitely worth a visit, the waterfalls and sitting by the ponds watching the terrapins and fish etc. One thing they loved was a waterfall where you could sit inside - great way to cool down. Toilets were very clean and there were water fountains for fresh drinking water to replenish your bottles. A little oasis - we tied this is with the Peak in the morning and then spent about two hours wandering through the park, getting a drink, ice-cream - a really beautiful place. When you walk through you then hit on Pacific Place so you can merge it into a full days intinerary. Highly recommended not just from me (sentimental reasons) but by two teenagers aswell!

A little bit a quiet in chaos!!. We took a weekday afternoon trip here and it was beautiful. So quiet after the hustle bustle of the main shopping areas of Hong Kong island. Immaculately kept and peaceful-- it was so theraputic-- watching people practice Tai Chi on a pagoda set in a lake./watching the turtles trying to catch the gold fish in the pond( got to admire their optimism- the fish were at least twice the size) There is an aviary there as well - some beautiful birds including parrots although i feel the cage areas are a bit small for such intelligent birds-- they seemed a bit distressed!

Butterflies. Home to butterflies, flora and fauna. The conservatory and bird sanctuary are free. Entrance to the peak train on one end, Pacific Palace on the other. HK Park connects Admiralty and Central, in a very stylish way.

Very clean and well paved!. You can spend hours in this parc, but do not forget that HK has dangerous animals as well such as the king cobra and other reptiles... but the parc is neat, clean, with very well displayed directions, and a great place for pick-nick!

Great Escape. This is located a very short walk behind the Conrad Hotel on HK island. It was certainly a delight to stroll through this Park on our way to the Peak Tram service. There is a huge variety of plants and they are really well positioned. There are many rest areas so take your time and explore carefully. It is just so quiet and peaceful in this magic park- away from the noise and hectic life of the island. Perfect location for a wedding- they have their own wedding reception area that looks very quaint.

great park..... we really loved this park. its so green and there so much greenery around and fresh air. this is a place you should definitely visit. we stayed there for an hour and realle enjoyed our visit. great time!

Versatile and compact. We spent a couple of hours here with our two boys. Lovely lunch in Thai Restaurant (mid-range pricing). Tea ware museum in old Flagstaff House was much more interesting than expected, esp. tea pot contest entries...kids loved them. Aviary is beautiful. Kids playground suited to under 5s. Easy access the Peak Tram station...we decided not to queue for 1.5 hours, and caught a taxi up instead.

Nice for a stroll away from the bustle. Not a big park but nice enough for a visit. It is well maintained and designed from bridges to waterfalls and lakes, aviary, playground, conservatory with many interesting flowering plants (like bat flower, hanging lobster claws), taichi garden, tea house (Lock Cha) and a museum (Teaware). Turtles were basking on rocks. Birds were busy. MTR station: Admirality.

Surprise. What a nice surprise to have such a nice park in the middle of all those buildings. There were monkeys, birds and reptiles. My camera ran out of batteries, or I'd have pics (I was truly disappointed). Very hilly, so you will get exercise! Free park.
Beautiful Park that you will remember. This is one of the world's most memorable parks for me. Don't miss the averies - huge with beautiful rare birlds flying around you.
beautiful park right downtown. very calm place to spend some time. excellent information boards on the birds one might see

A place to escape the city, for adults and children alike. This park is right in the middle of the city and caters for all ages. There is much to see and do- * The Flagstaff House Museum of Tea Ware - a colonial building housing a small (and free) museum giving a brief history of tea. Helpfully, there is a small room with wooden tea sets and cakes for small children.* Walk through Aviary* Children's Playground - large and on multiple areas- climbing frames/ slides / stepping blocks / sandpit / swings. The playground has good access for buggies and prams (somewhat unusual in HK)* Artificial Lake with Koi carp, other fish and terrapins* Bird Watching Tours* Restaurant (we haven't tried it)(and Marriage Registry- nice to see the brides, grooms and wedding parties.. HK style)Good for walks and children, to escape the city.
Hong Kong Park. The walk through avairy is fantastic and there are lots of different attractions within the park.
an oasis. from the Koi carp to the terrapins, the aviary and the zoo, just great way to take yourself out of the city streets for some quiet time.

relaxation. this is the place where you can go if you want silence. nobody will disturb you here plus the whole area gives a room for relaxation and keeps you out from all the stress you have in your body. a place where readers, painters and thinkers can go... it's good to have a quiet place inside the city that gives you freedom away from the city... hahaha=) did you get that? =)

Wonderful place to get away from the city. Hong Kong Park is similar to New York's Central Park, in that it is a great piece of nature surrounded by giant buildings. Seeing the birds and fish is a bonus too. The kids loved that!
Lots to see and do. Loved the Tea House and bird enclosure.. lovely peaceful location to walk around. Would be good for kids
Good fresh air. Good place to go for walk and fresh air. Good place to bring family, or for alone. Peaceful and much beauty!

Lock Cha Tea House is the reason you would visit here!. Firstly, you must book! This park on the hillside gives you fantastic vistas of the magnificent buildings in Centra ... however, the Lock Cha is my only reason for visiting the park ... traditional tea, plus they do a wonderful dim sum lunch or dinner
Nice park. Easy place to spend few moments. There is a nice sight tower, where you g´have to walk. Tea museum (small, but I liked) and some nice water falls for photo.

Bigger than I thought! Lots to see and do.. I trekked out here one day and visited the walk-thru Aviary (I loved seeing all of the different birds flying around as I walked across bridges in the middle), caged Aviary (a few of the birds in cages), Tai Chi Gardens with SARS memorial and Vantage Point (awesome view after 100 steps up the spiral tower), Olympic Square, the artificial lake (absolutely beautiful), the clock tower and the fountain plaza. It was a lot bigger park than I expected and it took me some time and I enjoyed it. You definitely have to be ready to take a hike to the walk-thru aviary. I didn't check out the gallery, museum of tea ware, children's playground or sports centers. I was there for the outside views, but if you have kids, I bet the playground was awesome considering the quality and size of the rest of the park.
Hong Kong Park. It is a park in between the Central and Admiralty. It is small comparing the the parks in Australia and New Zealand.
Nice place to visit. Nice one and restaurant in the center of it is quite attractive

Steep park and aviary was closed. Aviary not sccessible with stroler, and found out about it together with a note saying it was closed only after going up the hill pushing the stroler..... Not a good surprise... Plus at the admiralty station there are no lifts available..and had to take the stroler at escalators all along the way to get to the park...not safe! Although could be worth a visit if u use a baby carrier ( sling, moby wrap, baby bjorn.....). There is a cute tea museum,,,but upstairs not acessible by lifts... Couldnt find any baby facilities ( change station neither) .. So i used the one vailable at the mall by admiralty station...

Walk-through aviary. If you find yourself in Admiralty during the day, don't miss the walk-through aviary in Hong Kong Park. Family-friendly, free, and with a hoard of tropical birds flying around everywhere. Great fun.

Much needed green space in the Central district of Hong Kong. When visiting Hong Kong, it doesn't take long for the overwhelming crowds, traffic, noise and heat to have one searching for some a patch of green space just to relax and get away form the chaos of the city. This is where the very good Hong Kong Park serves both visitors and locals so very well. Near The Peak Terminus, you can find Hong Kong Park, which has many small (free) attractions and is well worth spending an hour or two at some point during your visit to the city. In addition to typical city park fountains and artificial lakes w/ fish and turtles, there is a very good aviary with several hundred tropical region birds flying around freely, many will perch on the walking deck just in front of you. The deck itself is well above ground level, creating a very nice experience, whether you like birds or not. There is also a conservatory building dedicated to plants, with two particularly interesting rooms. First, a dry room with cactus plants and then a humid room, with tropical flora. There is a tai chi garden area, a few statue and monuments and a very nice Tea Ware museum, found within the historic Flagstaff House, which is the longest standing western building in Hong Kong, built in the 1840s. These attractions are quite close together, thus you can visit them all in just an hour or so. Or you might want to just grab a park bench by one of the small ponds and enjoy being away from the maddening crowds and traffic to be found in the nearby streets of HK Island. Overall, we are big fans of Hong Kong Park, considering it our favorite in all of Hong Kong and we recommend spending a bit of time here when visiting the city if you need to get away from the crowds. Also, consider visiting the nearby Hong Kong Zoological and Botanical Gardens, not far from Hong Kong Park, offering a more wooded area, instead of city park, along with some animals on display. Combined these two attractions are a good way to spend time if you are visiting as families with young ones.
Nice park. Small, but just nice to walk trough on a warm day.
Beautiful Park. Hong Kong Park is the Central Park of Hong Kong. A beautiful oasis in the middle of a metropolis!

Haven of green in the city. I headed here after The Peak Tram - it's a great park, with a pond, observing tower and aviary (the latter is well worth a visit - you walk on suspended wooden walkways through a very large enclosed area that the birds can fly around in). There are turtles and fish in the ponds and a waterfall that you can walk behind, as well as an Olympic auditorium - worth a visit to relax and get away from the city. I exited via the nearby shopping mall that leads down to Admiralty MTR.

Good stroll in a lazy afternoon. We walked through this park from the Peak Tram station and it was a nice stroll in a very clean park. Relaxing to watch swimming turtles in the park's pond. There are benches in shady areas where it is nice to just read a book or listen to your i-pod.
well maintained. a lovely way to walk between our hotel and the peak tram. well maintained (as usual for hong kong) lots of water features
Park. The park is OK. But there are not too many plants and animals. I did not prefer to spend too much time in there.

A little tricky to get there. From the train station you basically have to go through the mall to get to the park. A nice place to take pictures and relax. Don't miss the aviary where they have a lot of nice birds.

A Good Walk. In such a highly populated city of Hong Kong, this one in Admiralty is a rare treasure. Everybody can enjoy a good walk for any length of time there. Besides a beautiful greenhouse, there're also a visual arts centre, a cafe, and other attractions such as birds and turtles.

Relaxing in a busy place. Hong Kong park is a wonderful place to sit and relax if you are on the island. It is literally an oasis in the middle of a concrete jungle.Stop by one of the nearby Pacific Coast Coffee shops for a cup of your favorite brew, get a little snack, and take them to the park for an enjoyable rest.

A stunning area of beautiful tranquility. Our hotel provided a little walking map that took us through this park! It is so peaceful and tranquil, you feel like you are a million miles away from the large city. There are beautiful walkways, fountains as well as unusual trees. We enjoyed the aviary garden too.It is immaculate!!
What a relief !. A welcome oasis amongst the hustle & bustle of the shopping areas with seating

A green spot in skyscraper jungle. Located close to Admirality station (exit C1), Hong Kong Park (est. 1991) helps you escaping the hustle and bustle of Central district. This oasis is completely artificial with waterfalls, exotic trees and flowers, fountains, ponds and small spots to relax. Its two main sights is a greenhouse with 3 different climate zones and the aviary which features more than 150 species of birds in a beautifully designed tropical "rainforest". There's also a tea museum which is admission-free and gives an insight into the Chinese tradition of tea.

great park for kids, good to walk thru to central from Pacific Place. large park in the middle of city -- next to botanical gardens, big playground on one end. if you're staying at Island Shangri-La, Conrad, Marriott etc by Pacific Place and it's not too hot, you can walk through the park to the Peak tram or down to Lan Kwai Fong and central area.
cool aviary. nothing too special but there's a cool walk-in aviary.it's free and right near the peak tram.http://growninsouthernground.wordpress.com/2012/05/30/hong-kong-day-2-peak-tram-parks/
Another nice park to walk aroung and stroll. Just go, spend some time. It is nice, green, and quiet. many poeple are there doing th esame thing. Enjoy a quiet moment.

A haven of peace amongst the madness of HK!. We took a few trips to the Park. The scenery and wildlife is fabulous. My only complaint is that the caged bird section is horrifyingly small and as an animal lover, that really bothered me. The walk through aviary, however, was huge and the birds had a lot of space to fly around. They had nearly extinct birds such as the Bali Myna, and they seemed to be in good condition. The tea place inside the park is really worth a visit, the staff were helpful and really knew their stuff. A great day out.
bird aviary closed for renovations. park well maintained and a cool relaxing spot in the middle of city. could improve signage.
Great family fun!. Lotsnofnfun but almost a whole day of fun and play!

Oasis in Hong Kong. It is a beautiful park for family and kids. The central pond and some of the viewing points featuring a green environment with high rises of a modern city are fantastic for photograhers. With a wedding registry in the park, the newly weds take pictures there as well. In between the five-star hotels in Admiralty and the the terminus of Peak Tram to take you to the Peak. So it is easy to make the Hong Kong Park part of your trip without spending too much time in your busy travel itinerary.
Peaceful oasis. Be sure to pop into the park when you are in the area. Make the most of it but having tea at Lock Cha Tea House while there.
Check out the terrapins!. Pretty little park amongst the high rises, provides lovely morning walk through fountains and ponds, don't forget to look for the terrapins!

Early morning serenity. In the middle of all the high rises and madness that is Hong Kong lies this oasis of tranquility (towards the bottom of Nathan Road)...seen at it's best in the early morning. From the break of dawn through to about 08.00h it is full of locals doing Tai Chi, either in large groups or as individuals. On the paths, in flower beds, under the banyan trees, there's hundreds of them! Others sit on benches, quietly singing to their sheet music. It is just the most surreal and spiritual place and gives you a real feel for life in this part of the world. It's well worth getting up early to witness. Nearest MTR Jordan.
Oasis of calm in the city jungle. Surrounded by trees, water fountains and the sound of singing birds you feel like in a green oasis while you can see the business towers through the trees.
A little breath in the middle of go go go. Loved the green, the gardens, the ponds and flamingos. I especially loved the Haida Totem from British Columbia!!

Beautiful spot in Central Hong Kong. A very nice park located in Central Hong Kong. My friend and I combined a walk through the park with a visit to the Museum of Tea Ware (located within the park itself) and some shopping at Pacific Place which is close by and easily accessible from the MTR. The park is well laid out, clean and very pretty. The aviary was the best part of the park; we spent a good deal of time watching and photographing the various birds, especially the Bali Mynahs, whose antics greatly amused us. Definitely worth a visit if you have some extra time in Hong Kong.
Japanese encephalitis?. We were not warned until we entered the aviary hat Japanese encephalitis was present and to turn around. I mean close the damn thing off for a couple of days!
Just a bypass. Nothing special. I walk through it only when I have to go from the Pacific Place to St. John's Cathedral.

Quiet place in the middle of the city. If you are looking for a peaceful spot in the city you should visit the park. There are nice walking paths and many places to sit and relax. The pond was under construction

Oasis within the center of the city. I didn't have that many chances to visit Hong Kong Park, but both times I did. It was rather memorable. The first time it was in 2008 as a tourist. Now I'm working here and I think Hong Kong park is like a good escape from the tall buildings of Central Hong Kong.I went there when sun was about the set and we went up the vantage point and I think it was just astonishing. The combination of the city and the park was nice. I'm from another big city myself, and these kind of landscape scene is not quite familiar. There are also many other areas worth seeing within Hong Kong park. So I would like to recommend any visitors to at least have to troll through the park when you have a chance. Maybe after the trip or before the trip up the peak! :)But I hope you all enjoy it as much as I do.
Take a break in the concrete jungle. Hong Kong Park is free, easy to get to and offers a nice respite from the hustle of Central/Admiralty. Go to see the aviary...it is well worth it.
Great for relaxing. It is so obvious that space and gardens are special here. Visit this park and understand the passion that is involved in keeping/maintaining these gardens..truly beautiful.
fresh air in central. fantastic park with easy access. excellent walks around with free aviary and wi fil in park able to get to easily from Admiralty stop and easy access to peak tram

Spring paradise. You can see kinds of bird around you. very exciting. beautiful waterfalls, romantic and relaxing. newly-married couple take their photos there. so sweet. I never miss the teapot museum. I learnt a lot about making Chinese tea. various teapots impressed me deeply and surprised me.

Great for a City Park. We enjoyed this park very much, which was recommended to us by a resident of the area. It is free, too! Do walk though the aviary. Part of the park and aviary were closed for renovations, but there was still plenty to see. We also walked up to the top of the viewing tower, nice view. The park is convenient to a shopping mall and the restoring power of Starbucks for an iced coffee. There is very good signage so you will not get lost.

Worth a visit. Beautiful garden in the heart of the city between skyscrapers. The garden is certainly worth a visit.In the park there is a collection of birds, held under natural conditions. Feeding stations used as observation points and photography.

a bit of green oasis in the middle of a concrete jungle.. Great for afternoon strolls while at lunch break. Great for bringing the kids and showing them the exotic birds and the fish and the waterfall and the turtles and the beautiful walks through the flora. I wish they let us sit on the grass as well. Thats the only drawback. But plenty of benches around. They used to have a lovely Thai restaurant there as well right in the middle with outdoor seating too, but last i checked it was closed down. Nonetheless one of my favourite peaceful places in Central!

Nice space to stop and smell the flowers.. Great place to sit and catch your breath, stay away from the cafe, under new management and a mess! Nice waterfall with fish and turtles. Walk up to the botanical garden from here.
excellent. Lovely green lung in the middle of a built up area with an avery which is free and lots of water features

Extraordinary. Plenty of seating creates an unusually transquil spot in the midst of HK's business centre. Excellent aviary and lakes. Look out for wedding parties, and if you're pecking L16 isnt half bad.
Loads of fun. There's a great fountain where you can duck under to get your photo and people watching is always good fun. The tea museum was interesting (free!) with interesting tea pot designs.

A pearl among the concrete forest. Hong Kong is a compact and interesting place and this park is a good example. After taking a tram ride (must do), eat at the very nice restaurants and shop at the spacious Pacific Mall, it is an excellent idea to take a walk in the Hong Kong Park next door. The size is big by Hong Kong standard (which one should have some idea when entering his hotel room) and it is compact (like the itinerary of Hong Kong people).There are nice walks around lily ponds, waterfall, gardens, colonial structure (a teapot museum nice to visit) and probably sights of newly weds taking pictures. Visit the greendhouse and aviary, especially good for the kids. Spend two hours there and then go across the park and take the Peak Tram to the Peak. That is my favourite itinerary for an overseas visitor.

What a break!!!. I moved to Hong Kong 15mnths ago. It is the perfect place to let your kids run after a heavy "searh for appartment" day, to relax after an anxious "tests to enter school" day, to see birds from the top of the trees (aviarium), to learn about the many kinds of tea, how are they grown and prepared (museum of tea)... or just to have lunch in this oasis in the middle of a working day at the office!!
An Oasis. An oasis in the heart of Hong Kong island. Easy to enjoy with the Teaware Museum and the Victoria Peak Tram

Great. Allocatea good number of hours for this visit. A photographers dream. Lovely clean park with free wi-fi. The Tea Museu.m is there - entrance is free - lovely gift shop inside. Outside in the park there are various other attractions e.g. the Loch Cha Tea Shop
A good resting point in the busy city.. Its a very very good point to get away from the noise in the city. Head to the park and you can see bankers trying to steal a nap! haha!
green in the heart of city. really like this place so much. Hidden gem in the busy city. close to tranportation centre, clean and it is well manage.
Very good. It's very small park, but very nice. For 1 hour walking and rest.
Nice. Wow, it's good for couple to walk around from late noon to evening with the brids sound around that area and see the noon view.

Little heaven in the middle of a bustling city. HK park is worth finding- I thought it was better than Kowloon park, although both offer different perks. Just don't get lost when you walk in. I kept wandering and almost forgot my way out. It was a great spot to relax, soak up the sun, check emails, and enjoy the scenery.

Concrete Park in a Concrete City. Given how much greenery there actually is in Hong Kong, Hong Kong Park is a poor excuse for a park - both absolutely and relatively to the beautiful parks in many of the other truly world class cities around the world. Really more of a concrete pathway between buildings where even if they built skyscrapers on the site they wouldn't even have a view. Sad but typical for Hong Kong.

A green paradise in the CBD. Actually there is not much to see in this park, but then it is a good place to have your sandwich lunch or afternoon tea relaxing in one of the benches and enjoying a bit of green in this busy CBD of Hong Kong. I see people jogging inside the park too.
Peaceful. This is a lovely park with smashing water gardens when the heat and the noise get too much - actually having just said that it is worth a visit in its own right!
Oasis. Very peaceful and relaxing, lots of locals and tourists

One of my favourite places. Hong Kong Park is by far one of my favourite attractions in HK. I visit the pro every time I am here. It is in the middle of the City, an oasis amongst trees with ponds, fish, birds and awesome gardens. Unfortunately the aviary was closed for renovations, which is my favourite part. You walk in through the gates, into a tropical oasis full of birds. The park itself has a great waterfall, which you can walk under, lots of ponds and great gardens and plants/flowers/trees. Definitely a place to get away to, especially as it is so close to the Peak Tram station (lower).
Quite nice. There were a lot of plants and was very convienent.

Hong Kong, what an amazing place. We had just left China and arrived in Hong Kong for a stay of 4 days. What a difference in culture.I will only review Hong Kong and Lantau Island in this review. Hong Kong is a very clean unpolluted place. 99% of the vehicles run on LPG no petrol or diesel fumes. Considering how densley populated Hong Kong is it was very refreshing to breathe unpolluted air and walk down, frequently washed streets. Even the seawater in Hong Kong was a clear aquamarine with fish clearly seen.It is a wonderful place. Easy to navigate on foot, train or bus. If ever you are stuck, apart from English almost being a first language and all signs in English, at least 5 Hong Kong Chinese leapt to our help without being prompted or being invasive. We had such a laugh with them when we were going on the right bus but wrong direction.The Star Ferry going to Hong Kong Island was brilliant. About 15 to 20 minutes to get across the harbour. Go at night see the brilliantly lit skyline. I have never been to New York but I thought it could look like Hong Kong. Wonderful laser show every night at 9pm at the water's edge on the harbour.Food was Cantonese with many, many western restaurants thrown in. (KFC, McDonalds, Steak houses, Cordon Bleu) 5* restaurants ranging to the humble street Chinese noodle restaurant. All immaculately clean and the service first class in all cases. Entertainment in most of these restaurants down on the harbour front. Going back to the Chinese, Cantonese fare, it would what you get in the UK. All restaurants were reasonably priced according the standard of the restaurant.The shopping in the electrical shops were about the same as the UK so, I did not pick a cheap Ipad..........shame. Lots of Asprey and Garrard type jewellers in the main shopping area of Napier St (I hope I have got the right name).Free WiFi everywhere even on the buses! Could not get over that!We only touched on Hong Kong and could have seen so much more.Lantau Island is now where the airport is situated. No longer skimming the roof topson the mainland, so we missed that experience.We also visited the huge Bhudda on Lantau Island. We did not take the organised tour but made the journey ourselves by bus and train. Very easy to do and cost us about £10 for two including getting a drink. The tour can cost up to £45 each but you do get a meal. I would highly recommend a visit to anyone.

If you have time - take a leisurely stroll. through Hong Kong Park. Birds, trees, and people watching. Remember, in Hong Kong, you can walk around openly with a beer or other alcohol. Buy these from the Circle K or 7-Eleven and take it to the park. Cop a squat and people watch!

Nice Park with lots of space to frolic!. This was next to our hotel so we decided to walk over. It turned into a whole day event for us, walking around the park. Lots to do. The bird sanctuary. Tai Chi square. The indoor Garden area. And the Tea House. And plenty of shade to cool off in the hot hot October weather we experienced.
Great place to relax. Well laid out and relaxing atmosphere, an oasis of calm in a bustling city
HK Park. Great way to spend some time in the city. Beautiful relaxing walk inside the city

Lovely place to relax and get away from the city. I work close to the park and often come here to eat my lunch on a shady bench. It is a lovely park around a lake. It is lovely to walk around and enjoy the trees and flowers. There is a huge walk in avery which is great fun too. It is very easy to get to. You can walk up through central, up the Battery Path, past the cathedral and throught the city bank building on the way to the peak tram - a very pleasant walk. In the park there is a tea museum and a wonderful traditional tea house as well as a restaurant and wine bar.

An oasis in a concrete jungle.. We spent a few hours here on a lovely day in March. We walked with friends and enjoyed the peace of the trees, flowers, and birds. There is an amazing double helix tower to climb near the Sars Memorial (also a peaceful, reflective spot). The park seems to be a popular spot for weddings--we saw two while we were there. We could hear the birds singing throughout the park and there were waterfalls and fountains around. An enjoyable day.

A great oasis. In a sea of concrete, Hong Kong Park still provides a little respite from the energy and frenetic crowds. The teawares museum is delightful, with instructional videos that are really (unintentionally) hilarious. Definitely worth seeking out.

Oasis in a global metropolis. Hong Kong is a famously crowded global metropolis on a very small amount of flat land, mostly surrounded by rather rugged terrain. Just a stone's throw from the international commercial activity of Central and Admiralty is the pristine Hong Kong Park. The gardens are beautiful and provide welcome tranquility in what can be a noisy city. The Museum of Tea Ware is a sterling institution that showcases tea culture, tea history and the best entries in the annual teapot-making competition held in Hong Kong. The aviary further up the hill is also a good zoological asset for Hong Kong worth a visit.

Peace in the centre of the city. The park is very diverse and although it is entirely man made it feels good. The walk through aviary (closed for a few weeks for renovation) is amazing. Some interseting sights as the registry office is part of the park
Quite good!. I'm not sure what I expected when entering HK Park, but I definitely enjoyed part of an afternoon spent walking around taking pictures.
Nice and well-kept. Really nice park in the middle of rushing and noisy city. The place, where to get some peace, relax and be calm. Beautiful light-fontain!

Unmissable. This was not our first visit to Hong Kong but how we came to miss this gem we do not know. Unfortunately the walk through avairy was closed for renovation but all the other attractions almost made up for that fact. The Tea Museum was fascinating and we had the bonus of seeing the winning entrants of a pottery competiton to design a Chinese teaset. What inovation! The conservatory on the ground floor was full of the perfume of spring flowers. Steps led up to a amazing cactus collection and then down to a tropical plant display. Out side the park was a delight of floral displays, ponds brimming with fish and turtles, as well as fountains and waterfalls. This park was once the site of a British Army Baracks and only a genius could have conceived this transformation. Do not miss!
Great park to bring little kids too. Fountains, birds and loads of open spaces for kids to run around and play. We didn't take advantage of it enough!
A green break from shopping. Surrounded by skyscrapers and fancy malls, HK Park is indeed and oasis - a break from the commerce all around

Greenery in the City. Nice to have a largish green area in the city. Butterflies, bird aviary, fish, waterfall & turtle pond & look out tower (105 stairs).Bird life is prolific & bird lovers delight.Relaxing place to take sandwich to eat., although you are not allowed on the grass. There are various seats to sit on.

do you like birds ?. This park has all for you to see many areas for children older folks.
we walked park for a whole day and saw half what they had. Bird sanctuary is sweet nice place to see the exotic birds of china.
Nice.. Good for city bird watching, but some steep steps also a little zoo.

Disney land Hong kong. Worth a look, typical Disney stuff a little over priced. The best thing is the dedicated train it drops you right at the gate. It is worth going mid week as weekends get crowded. As with all DisneyThem parks it a little to cutie for me, if you have kids they will love it. A one off for me, quite cheap apart from the food. Caution it gets really hot in the summer.

Feathers and Forest in a concrete Jungle. A wonderland of birds and plants in the middle of tall elegant skyscrapers, great for a rest from the hustle and bustle. The aviaries aare impressive but sadly the walk through aviary was closed for maintenance. The naturalised and slightly diminuitive feral sulphur crested cockatoos were a very entertaining consolation prize flitting between trees and buildings!

Polluted greenery. Don't expect to be able to breathe a healthier air by going into Hong Kong parks. It is polluted just the same. The surrounding sky scrappers make you feel trapped in a zoo or some kind of sick reserve. No activities are allowed apart from walking or chasing for a free space on a bench. Makes you feel awkward to relax.
A great walk. You gotta love a city that carves out great parks in big cities! Definitely worth the trip!
Nice place, but far too busy!. I went here on a Sat afternoon and it was crazy busy and noisy, but nice all the same. Do not go on a weekend!!
Don't miss this park!. I love the beautifully-designed walkways and plant life and also the aviary. It's a wonderful refuge from the hustle and bustle of HK streets.

Worth your time!. Lovely park with great gardens, wildlife area and aviary. Great place for children, also has wonderful outdoor pool as well as indoor pool. Outdoor maze for a great game of hide and seek.
Great Park and City Contrast. Great park, loads to do. worth taking a picnic. A great way to spend an afternoon away from the busy city.

HK Botanical and Zoological Garden. HK Park is east of the lower Peak tram terminal, so if you are here, then walk west -- opposite, the other side of PT terminal, to get to the HK Botanical and Zoological park. Gorgeous birds, plants on a steep hillside. Washroom and tea room. Very lovely spot.

What a beautiful Park. Hong Kong Park is settled in between the big office buildings and major hotels. It is a very beautiful designed Park with fountains and a lake. In one of the corners there is the tea museum. Worth to visit, if you like tea. When you walk through the park, it is also the direction to the Peak tram, when you come from the direction of the Conrad and Shangri La Hotels.

If you like tea and nature visit Hong Kong Park. The Flagstaffe Museum of Tea Ware is situated here and entrance is free. It shows the art of tea plus tea ware - an amazing collection, plus a modern exhibit of recently made tea bowls and tea pots - from the traditional to the whacky! They have a tea shop which serves tea in the traditional way but it is expensive but great for a new experience!The park is beautiful with flowers, trees and pools with wonderful fish and there is an aviary - a really lovely place to visit!
Alright. Much smaller than I was expecting, and not really anything special. Good to see some green space in the concrete jungle that is Hong Kong though!

A wonderful little oasis. Considering its location in between Central and Admiralty, and easy access from offices and a major shopping centre (Pacific Place, up all the escalators on the right and out the back of the top floor), this park has so much to see. The Aviary is superb, well-maintained and very clean and safe; botanical specimens well-labelled, the Tea Museum (free admission when it's open), turtles sunning themselves on rocks in the pools, a nifty waterfall you can walk behind, a cactus house, childrens' play areas, tai-chi area, SARS memorial, some of the largest pigeons in the world (from New Guinea)--and the whole thing for free. I go in there often and enjoy the quiet environment and watching the occasional small clump of school children on their field trips. It's quite nice and you can't beat the cost.

walk in the park. guess i found it alike to new york's central park but way smaller and just do not feel that i have walked out of the business district although some people did look really relaxed in the park
Birds in the city and a special flower!. Well worth a look, especially the walk-through aviary and one of the few places to see the 'Hong Kong orchid'.
Tea House. Visited the tea house museum which also provides free internet. Sat by the fountain and in the park, very relaxing and peaceful.
Well maintained, nice place to relax.. Beautiful and very easy to get there. Right behind the Conrad.

Must see in Hong Kong. There's really something for everyone in Hong Kong Park.The highlight for me is the walk-in aviary, a huge structure with hundreds of exotic birds. There's an elevated walkway from which you can observe the birds. It's a quiet, almost meditative space with subtropical plants and constant chirping of birds. It's not especially crowded with people. If you're bringing a camera, bring a good one -- you won't get very far with a point and shoot (lighting isn't good enough without a fast lense), but there are some serious photographers here.Also definitely worth seeing are the conservatory and the artificial lake.

Cool. I agreed to meet a travel buddy here at Hong Kong Park to start my Central self-guided tour. Pretty nice park with people walking around -- mostly tourists and people getting to their offices. There is a big aviary (Edward Youde) which we skipped due to the avian flu scare. However, the nice surpises were the lookout point where we had to climb 100+ steps as well as the Tai Chi area which had some SARS heroes tribute and sculptures.The pond is serene and it would have been nice if one could just sit there and while the morning away.
An oasis. Lovely park which makes you feel a world away from the crowds. Features a lovely aviary, teaware museum and sculptures. Don't miss.

Lovely and peaceful. Been to Hong Kong several times and only recently on my last visit, discovered the park (on the way to the peak tram) - an absolute must if you just want to break away from the busy streets of hong kong. A peaceful and lovely walk with my partner and 6 month baby (and its free!).

how bizarre. someone told us that one of the interesting things about HK is that you can't hear birds anywhere, they got rid of them all due to bird flu. That may be the case but the aviary in HK park is absolutely worth a visit. Even with half of it closed due to renovations it was a wonderful big, airy, colourful and interesting sight to see. The rest of the park is lovely as well, full of what looked like graduating students with horrible fluffy toys as souvenirs and the usual sprinkling of young couples looking for somewhere a bit more peaceful in the heart of a very busy city.

Good walk.. Here is park for walking around near admiralty and the business district. Very serene people take post lunch walks so you can digest Chinese food.... Veri scenic greenery anda few birds as well... Few sitting areas and fish pond is nice

A nice break in the middle of the city. Lots to do in Hong Kong Park, take a stroll, watch the turtles in the pond, or walk up to the aviary. There is also a teaware museum and tea house in the park, as well as many places to sit and watch the city go by. One word of warning, the park is on a hill, and given how hot and humid it can be in HK, you may want to take it slow!

A Wonderful Aviary!. This park is delightful! The ponds have lots of koi and cute turtles sunning themselves, but then there is also the option of walking through the tented aviary and seeing all kinds of wonderful birds! And, it's free!
Escape from commercialism. Nice place to stroll and get away from the shopping. Some hilly areas. Loved the aviary.

A quiet oasis.. Situated behind Pacific Place shopping mall, this small park is lovely. A small lake, statues, trees, flowers, a tea museum and a large aviary which you can walk through. All free! A good place to relax and take a break from your shopping for an hour.

a good place to take a break amidst the hustle and bustle of the city. it's great to spend an hour or so at the Hong Kong Park after shopping at the Pacific Place....it's just a few minutes walk away...don't miss out the bird sanctuary..one can watch the colourful birds flying around at close proximity...there's no need for binoculars!
Nice park in the city. I enjoy using this as a walk through to get me off the crowded streets
Very quiet and relaxing. A little oasis of calm in the madness that is Hong Kong downtown area

Nice gardens, and a great aviary. Plus, it's free!. A nice escape from the shopping chaos of the city. It has a few nice gardens, a view point tower and a nice aviary. Great place to have a picnic, I suppose. There was also a few old buildings and a tea museum, and some plants!

a peaceful spot in the city. a great place for kids and adults alike. Inside, there's a couple of museums and a lovely tea house to take a rest. Take a stroll through the wonderful aviary and exit near the fish and turtle ponds where it's just nice to sit and people watch.

Beautiful - a great find!. We had just returned from the Peak and were going to find a taxi to get us back to our Hotel - it had been a long day in very warm weather, but decided to walk some of the way. Let's face it no where is very far from somewhere else in Hong Kong.
