We were ambling along and came across the gates to the park, all looked at each other then said lets go in for a bit of a look (not realising exactly what this place was). We were all so pleased that we did it was the most beautiful place and to know that these gardens were in amongst so many massive buildings is unbelievable. There was a wedding party in their having photos taken and so many people sitting and taking in the serenity or just wandering around - but it was not crowded. Lots of lakes and little rivers - the chinese love water and fish as we all know. A beautiful waterfall where you could go in behind. Then the bird aviary which was just wonderful. We probably spent a couple of hours there and could have stayed longer except that it was getting late, we had been on the go all day (and just returned from the peak) and had a 14 month old toddler with us (luckily she slept in her rucksack when she got too tired). We were a little confused as to exactly where we were and left by one gate, which actually took us to the bottom of the road on which our hotel was situated but the opposite end. As it turned out had we gone out the gate just on the opposite side, but which was up the hill we would have left the park very near to our hotel. Never mind it was great just walking around and seeing things you wouldn't if you had taken a taxi or a bus.A visit to Hong Kong Park is a definate necessity should you visit this wonderful city.

An oasis. Okay, an oasis with hills.. Loved the aviary. Spend some time there. Great photo opportunities -- the birds are gorgeous, varied, and tame. Locals enjoy showing off their photos, so be ready to ooh and ah. Walking to or through the park involves some hill climbing and the accompanying vistas -- enjoy!

Very pleasant but beware the hills. We went on a very hot day and found the gradients daunting. We are both reasonably fit but wilt a bit in the heat. It was also on the second day of a 2 day stopover when we were still jetlagged and the previous day was hectic.We enjoyed the aviary and the general ambience of the place. On a cooler day it would be 5 stars.

Oasis of calm. Always worth travelling the escalator up from Pacific Place to hang out for a while in the Park and Aviary - fun to watch wedding parties having their photos taken - little lake/pond full of terrapins and fish very attractive - great (free!) aviary - locals tend to stomp through but that is their way - the birds seem used to it! Addition since I was last there - moving memorial (bronzes) to the medical professionals who gave their lives helping others during the SARS outbreak in 1993.

An oasis of tranquility and beauty surrounded by skyscrapers. If you need together away from the intense and dynamic atmosphere of HK city, then consider HK park. Situated near Admiralty station, it's easy to get to and is a picturesque break from busy, urban HK life. There are some beautiful old colonial buildings and some great landscaped gardens and water features to see. If you explore the place fully there is a nice aviary and also a large viewing tower with awesome views of the park.
Green Haven. Right in the middle of the city this park is also an aviary, a botanic garden and host two museums and a restaurant. I go there as often as I can.
Magical. Lovely wee spot in the city. Awesome to see the fish and turtles swimming oblivious to the madness going on around them!
amazing. you walk through the noise and hustle of Hong kong and then through the gate of the park and ... instant silence and calm, free wifi as well such a beautifull place too hard to describe
Serene. Went here early at 8.30am. The landscape is green and has a nice walk. Its nice to be here to enjoy the beautiful nature surroundings away from the bustling city.
A small haven. Well planned and full of locals meeting for lunch, practising Tai Chi and other martial arts. Just off the bustling streets and yet beautifully calm and tranquill.

Great to escape crowds. Lovely park with beautiful lakes with fish turtles and birds, you must walk through the aviary and the Tai Chi garden is fascinating. The ark also gives superb views of Bank of China building and Lippo Towers
Great aviary in Hong Kong Park. Great aviary to enjoy birds swooping overhead (close too!)

Beautiful little oasis in the city. We chanced upon the park on our way back to the MTR from the tram ride. What a surprisingly fun and beautiful park! There are lots of pretty little bird habitat from where you can admire all kinds of tropical birds. I loved it. The flagship museum of tea ware is also on one end fo the park and totally worth the detour. Will go again.

A Nice Park on the way to the Peak tram. A block or so from the Peak tram you will find HK park, truly an oasis in the city. Not well marked but well worth seeing. A cool area with a lake, some great shots of some of the nearby buildings, and a wedding registry and more all there. Not really in my tourbook either. Not large and easily accessed this park provides you with a wonderful place to "chill" in the big city. The park has lots of small attractions such as an aviary and an Olympic area also. It is within short walking distance of the Star Ferry Pier -one of them and then the other way is the Peak tram stop. Worth a 15-30 minute stop.
NOT TO BE MISSED. What an absolute devine place.I was walking throug and could not leave,explored for 2 hours.
very pretty. very pretty park. got a little hot after midday. good for a picnic.

A lovely detour to take and just....catch your breath!. As others have stated, this is a great park, a haven of tranquility in the centre of Kowloon, just off the hustle and bustle of Nathan Rd's busy shopping. A lovely way to take a stroll away from the crowds, see the flamingos, some tai chi, eat an ice cream and catch your breath until you're ready to face the madness of HK in full speed again!
A walk in the park.. Passed by here whilst i was out shopping one day & thinks its a really nice area just to take a leisurely stroll & you get some great views of the city too.

Oasis. I loved strolling through Hong Kong Park. The sidewalks outside were crowded and bustling, but inside the Park it was quiet. People were polite, and it felt like there was room to breathe. I loved the Aviary and the birds. A treat on a busy afternoon.

Oasis in HK. Right across the street from the Peak tram you will find HK park, truly an oasis in the city. Not large and easily accessed this park provides you with a wonderful place to "chill" in the big city. The park has lots of small attractions such as an aviary and a great Ti chi area. It is within short walking distance of the Star Ferry Pier and a great place to fit between the ferry ride and the Peak tram.... Enjoy

relax. The park is an oasis in Hong Kong where you can walk slowly, sit and relax and watch the terips and fish. There is a small cafe/restaurant there where you can get a drink and a snack. It is next to Admiralty metro staion and the Shangrila Hotel. 5 minutes walk to the peak tram.
Beautiful Aviary. What a super aviary in the centre of Hong Kong. It was so large and visitors walk into it. Beautiful.

An Oasis. Fresh air, birds in a huge walk-in aviary as well as free-flying, water features with Koi carps and turtles, a tea museum and art gallery, accessible from mid-levels, the Peak Tram Terminus, Admiralty and Central, it is a peaceful place to spend an hour or two to relax and unwind. Take some time and explore it, or split it over a few days!

This is the best fun walk in Hong kong for all ages. great levels and even the older generation can walk the park and get fresh air....squash center for the really energetic...animals from everywhere....world class stuff
Lovely oasis. It was a delight to discover this several years ago. It seemed a most popular wedding photography site when we were last there!Try the teahouse there.
Very nice place to relax.. Make sure you used the escalator, very high up to go to the park but was lovely.
A paradise in the city. The conservatory and plants are good, but get into the aviery the birds will light up your day
Large fish with large birds of prey hovering. Fountains amazing, place full of photographes watching the fish and turtles rising. Lively friendly atmosphere and nicely close to the tram stop.

Excellent Park in the city. We loved this park. It is in the middle of the city of HongKong and there was so much to see. Birds in an aviary, turtles and fish ponds etc. Travelling with a toddler that absolutely loves birds made this park one of the highlights of the trip and it is free.
Very relaxing. A walk through the park is very relaxing and the area is well presented and if you go in the morning, you'll see people practising tai chi and other various exercises

Great little oasis. This is a great little oasis in the midst of downtown Hong Kong (with the entrance close by the Peak Tram terminal). The grounds are immaculate, and there's a lookout tower which gives a great view of the skyline. Very scenic and relaxing.

I like the environment there. Recommend for the Outdoor Bird Aviary,a awesome place to improve photographer skills. And visual art museum will change the theme difference it is also a good place to visit

A compact Gem in the center of the city. The grounds are so well manicured. I love the Aviary, the birds, they all have such character. The fountains are beautiful, and if the weather is nice, there are ALWAYS wedding photo parties happening. I have always been fascinated with tea and the tea ceremony, and the tea house museum is a must see.
Alittle of this and that. Want to have a relaxing walk and afternoon? This is the place, bring your camera and comfortable shoes.
Great place. Would definitely come back to Hong Kong! I love this place and cant wait to be back!

Peace and tranquility in the centre of chaos.. Within a few minutes walk of both the peak tram and the bank of china is this man made oasis of calm. Having done no research on this park, we came across it by chance as a diversion on the way to the peak. It was amazing to find such calm amid the surrounding skyscrapers and was well worth the detour. 5 minutes of serenity in a city that never stops !

Beautiful green patch in the middle of skycrapers jungle. If you went for a Peak tram ride early, upon arriving back down again at Cotton Tree Drive cross the big hilly road and you will be at Hong Kong Park. Really a very nice serene place, it is quite big really with beautiful ponds and a tropical conservatory (they even have coffee plants there too) and a big bird aviary that is quite interesting to visit. Beautiful birds from South east asia and parts of China are portrayed there. Entrances are free. Walking on tall boardwalk at the tree tops were fun for my toddler, you can push your stroller in. There are children playground and a cute little teaware museum. Dont go on Tuesdays,it is closed.

Excellent. Don't miss out on this one, it's a great place! On Saturdays you can see plenty of just married couples doing their phot shoots. A walk in the bird reservation is a must! So many beautiful birds and you are walking on the bridge built high enough to walk among the top of the trees.

Hong Kong Park. Smack in the middle of the city. A fantastic place to relax and kick back. Most trees are ID as to their genus ans species. The aviary is excellent with many photo ops. Bye the way, it's free, free, free. Take a couple of hours and enjoy yourself.
Green among the skyscrapers. Lovely water features and wildlife. Easy to navigate. Good respite from the hectic, hot city.
A great find. One of our favourite places, so peaceful and we loved the aviary.

Surprising Oasis in the Middle of Business District. In the midst of the business towers and shops of busy Central District, the Hong Kong government has created a beautiful, modern and relaxing 8 hectares park, free for the use of its citizens.One way to access the park is through Pacific Place Mall. There is an escalator which takes you up. Once there, you can wander around and enjoy the facilities as well as the natural landscape, waterfalls and ponds.The park was built on the site of a former garrison, and some of the historic buildings, built between 1842 and 1910, have been preserved. Notably, the former residence of the Commander-in-Chief of the British Armed Forces, known as Flagstaff House, is now the interesting Flagstaff House Museum of Teaware, and the Cassels Block is now the Hong Kong Visual Arts Centre. In the centre of the park is a waterfall and lake. There are also two very modern facilities, the Conservatory and the Aviary, built on the hillside near the Tai Chi Garden and the Vantage Point. Other facilities include the Sports Centre housing a variety of sports activities, the Squash Centre housing 12 air-conditioned courts with a restaurant, a large carpetted children's playground on many levels, a Central Garden surrounded by grand columns and a dancing fountain in the middle, the Olympic Square - a mini Greek theatre which hosts various entertainment events, the Vantage Point tower, which affords a panoramic view of the park and the surrounding scenery, the Tai Chi garden - a long collonade with gardens, courtyards and bonzai trees. There is a restaurant if you need refreshments or a meal.This beautiful park, with its many facilities, is worth a visit as a respite from the crowds of Central. You will enjoy its many restful corners among the fantastic skyscrapers surrounding the park, and the gracefully designed landscaping and facilities.
Nice oasis in middle of Central HK. Very peaceful park with teaware museum and tea house in central HK. Very pleasant.

A quiet place even on a holiday!. There is something for everyone here, from fountains, a waterfall, flowers, ponds to an aviary and trails. It is large enough to enable hundreds of people to be there with comfort and always a "quiet" place to find near the aviary. It is good for someone taking a quiet time by themselves or for families.

nobody told me such an oasis existed in the middle of HK!. This is a large, beautiful park with hills, lakes, gardens, a bird park, a memorial, an open theatre and much more. When one talks about going to HK, no one mentions a park in the middle of the city. I stumbled upon the park accidentally and spent a couple of hours exploring it. It is a great escape.

Unbelievable. We went to the park and saw the bird garden. It was so thrilling to see so many exotic birds. We did not however, see the one bird we really wanted to see and that is the New Guinea Bird of Paradise, which has got to be the most breath taking creature I have ever seen.

A great piece of nature in the middle of a crazy city!. I live in Hong Kong so I've been to this park dozens of times! Each time I go I love it! It's not that big but it gives you the impression that you are in the middle of a forest with water around you. You forget the city noise and life once inside the park. You can see turtles, lots of birds and waterfalls. You can even go up to a view point where you can have a look at the city from the top.You can get there by walk from Central. It 's near admiralty mtr station. The tram also stops not fare away from there.Inside the park there's even a free tea museum! Pretty interesting stuff.You've got also some places to eat and drink.A must seen when in Hong Kong!

Surprisingly beautiful urban park. This is a perfect place to spend an hour or two relaxing in Central. It's hard to imagine finding such a beautiful peaceful place amid all the bustle of the area, but it's there. Relax and enjoy. We may not have seen it all, but the waterfall, fountains, avairy, fish, turtles, ponds and overall landscaping were highlights. There were several wedding parties, along with photographers taking advantage of the scenery and photo opportunities. Very clean and nicely maintainned. Nice resturant in center of the park and the Tea Museum which I'll review seperately (not to be missed).

what a suprise a great space with lots to see. we entered the park to walk to the zoo only to dicover the park is worth a visit as well the paths lead to large water features a fountains the ponds are full of fish and terrapins and then you discover the birds it like entering a cage from the film jurassic park and you walk around the tree top walk way and there are an array of brightly coloured birds.and it is all free !!!

As far as space allows and city parks go, this is an excellent park. Ok... This is no Hyde Park or Central Park nor will you find anything of that nature in Hong Kong due to a lack of space. However, considering the constraints faced in this mega-city, Hong Kong Park along with the Zoological and Botanical Gardens nearby make up a perfect escape from the chaos and madness that is Hong Kong on most streets. Hong Kong park features a couple of small watersheds with fish and turtles as well as a large man made waterfall area, with benches and bridges. This, in effort to help you forget that you are just a few dozen meters from serious foot and road traffic, it effectively does the trick of pulling you into nature, in the middle of the city. The highlight of the Hong Kong Park is a very good outdoor Aviary, allowing visitors to walk a long platform that is 30 meters above the ground. Here you will see and get up and personal with exotic birds flying above, below and in front of you. Its a great place to practice your photography skills and just enjoy being in a natural environment, along with lovely birds. Hong Kong Park is accessible from Admiralty and Central MTR stations and are not far from the Peak Tram and attractions, just follow the little signs and you'll be there in no time. Ideally, this park is visited along with the Zoological and Botanical Garden nearby where many animal species are on display.
Escape in Central. One of the few places you can escape Central Hong Kong during a lunch break.

Surprising. I went with my husband, very quiet we able to take many pictures as not many people that day, we were surprised that Hong Kong will have such natrure in such busy city. Easy to find and close to the central and shopping mall. Was perfect to escape noise pollution & to be surrounded by the birds!

Victoria Barracks. This was the location of the former British Victoria Barracks and house for the Commander of the British armed forces (which is now the Flagstaff Tea Museum). You can still still British quarters in the park but you have to look for them. The park itself is a nice spot just to relax and people watch especially after a busy day of shopping or visiting the other tourist attractions.. You will see hords of people with cameras trying to take photos of birds and fish at the park. You can also see graduates and wedding couples getting their photos taken. The big fountain is a place to take your photo. How wet you want to get is up to you.

With 4 kids in tow, it was the perfect day out. The children's area kept our kids busy for hours and us, the mums, could have an adult conversation! We made the mistake of taking our pram and the park is just not pram friendly with so many flights of steps. The cafe served good food and the aviary held the kids interest for 3 mins inspite of its beautiful layout.Overall, a must see visit if you're travelling with kids.

A quiet stroll through beautiful setting. A little known botanical garden and zoo in the heart of central. Most locals are even unaware that this place exists or haven't been there since they were children. Don't let their descriptions keep you from visiting this beautiful place! They have small gardens interspersed within a park. The zoo mostly consists of a large aviary section and a large primate section. They have small monkeys - smaller than your hand and monkeys like orangatangs, gibbons, and lemurs. It is difffently a beautiful stroll through the middle of the city. My friends and I enjoyed our day trip to see this park. If you do a search for Hong Kong zoo, you will find the offical site, complete with a list of animals at the zoo and pictures. Beautiful place!

More than just a park. nicely kept park, with ponds, gardens, and even a manmade waterfall. the HK people love their parks. we went on a sunday and it was crowded as could be, and we went again on monday and it was almost deserted. so i definately recommend going during the week while the locals are working.the park contains and observation tower, a fairly large aviary, a conservatory, the flagstaff tea museum, and a few other attractions. there are some fairly rigorous steps to climb or you can take the longer way around the park. we spent almost half a day wandering around there, and we still didnt really explore it all.

Nice little green space in the city. Hong Kong park offers a nice escape from the bustling streets of Central/admiralty. The park includes well kept pathways, a small man-made pond and waterfall, and a bird aviary. It was relaxing to walk through the trees and hear so many bird calls that I had never heard before. Hong Kong Park is much smaller than Victoria Park to the east, but it is a very short walk from the waterfront area around Central.
